{{Infobox person | image = File:Angela Gheorghiu as Floria Tosca at San Francisco Opera, November 2012.jpg | alt = | caption = Gheorghiu as Floria [[Tosca]] at San Francisco Opera, November 2012 | image_size = 250 | birth_name = Angela Burlacu | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1965|9|7}} | birth_place = [[Adjud]], [[Socialist Republic of Romania]] | death_date = | death_place = | education = [[National University of Music Bucharest]] | occupation = Opera singer ([[soprano]]) | years_active = 1990–present | spouse = | website = {{URL|angelagheorghiu.com}} }} '''Angela Gheorghiu''' ({{IPA-ro|anˈd͡ʒela ɡe̯orˈɡi.u|-|Ro-Angela Gheorghiu.ogg}}; née '''Burlacu'''; born 7 September 1965) is a Romanian [[soprano]].<ref>[[John Warrack]] and Ewan West, 'Gheorghiu, Angela', ''The Concise Oxford Dictionary of Opera'', Oxford University Press, 1996; [[Nicolas Slonimsky]] and Laura Diane Kuhn, ''[[Baker's Biographical Dictionary of Musicians]]'', Gale Group, 2001, p. 1264; David M. Cummings, [https://books.google.com/books?id=48V3kmpJEEgC&pg=PA9 "Gheorghiu, Angela"], ''International Who's Who in Classical Music'', Routledge, 2003, p. 274</ref>
Since her professional debut in 1990, she has performed in leading roles of several operas at New York's [[Metropolitan Opera]], London's [[Royal Opera House]], the [[Vienna State Opera]], Milan's [[La Scala]], and many other opera houses in Europe and the United States. She has a substantial discography primarily with [[EMI Classics]] and [[Decca Records|Decca]] and is especially known for her performances in the operas of [[Giacomo Puccini|Puccini]].
== Biography == Gheorghiu was born in 1965 in [[Adjud]], Romania. Along with her sister [[Elena Dan]], she sang opera music from an early age.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.jcarreras.homestead.com/AlagnaArtPeople1999.html|title=Roberto Alagna – People Magazine 21 June 1999|website=www.jcarreras.homestead.com}}</ref> At age 14, Gheorghiu began to study singing at the [[National University of Music Bucharest]], primarily under Mia Barbu. Her graduation in 1990 followed the overthrow of [[Nicolae Ceaușescu]] the previous year, enabling her to seek an international career immediately. Her professional opera debut took place at the [[Cluj-Napoca Romanian National Opera]] as Mimì in ''[[La bohème]]'' in 1990, the same year she won third prize in the Belvedere International Competition.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.belvedere-competition.com/winners/|title=Belvedere-Competition: Winners|website=www.belvedere-competition.com}}</ref>
Gheorghiu made her international debut in 1992 at the [[Royal Opera House]] as Zerlina in ''[[Don Giovanni]]''.<ref>[http://www.angelagheorghiu.com/files/biography/biography-en.pdf Biography on Official website (2004)] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080828005043/http://www.angelagheorghiu.com/files/biography/biography-en.pdf |date=August 28, 2008 }}</ref> She debuted at the [[Vienna State Opera]] as Adina in ''[[L'elisir d'amore]]'' and at the [[Metropolitan Opera]] as Mimì in ''La bohème''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.metoperafamily.org/metopera/season/bio.aspx?id=690&type=1|title=Biography of Angela Gheorghiu |publisher=The Metropolitan Opera}}</ref> In 1994, she was auditioned by the conductor Sir [[Georg Solti]] for a new production of ''[[La traviata]]'' at the Royal Opera House. Her debut as Violetta led her to international stardom.
Gheorghiu has concentrated her repertoire on several different roles: Violetta, Mimì, [[La rondine|Magda]], Adina, and [[Roméo et Juliette|Juliette]]. In 2003, she debuted as Nedda in ''[[Pagliacci]]'' and as Marguerite in ''[[Faust (opera)|Faust]]''. A soprano with a large range and a dark coloured voice,<ref>Crory, Neil (2005) "Recommended CD Recordings: Puccini: Angela Gheorghiu" [[Opera Canada]] 46(2): p. 47</ref> Gheorghiu is also able to sing ''[[spinto]]'' roles. She has recorded ''[[Tosca]]'' (also made into a film in 2001, directed by the French director [[Benoît Jacquot]]) and Leonora in ''[[Il trovatore]]'' for EMI and sang in her first Tosca at the Royal Opera House, Covent Garden, in 2006. Her performance was an overall success, although because the famous [[Franco Zeffirelli|Zeffirelli]] production of 1964 was replaced by a new production (which premiered with her), there was comparison between the Toscas of Gheorghiu and [[Maria Callas]], for whom the Zeffirelli production was designed.
Gheorghiu took part in many concerts, singing alone or together with her colleagues. Among the most important ones, the reopening of the Royal Opera House Covent Garden (1999) and [[Teatro Malibran]] in Venice (2001) and at the opening the new Opera House in Valencia, in the presence of the [[Queen Sofia]] of Spain (2005). She sang at the [[Prom at the Palace]] (2002), the event that marked the [[Golden Jubilee of Elizabeth II]], a concert that is available on DVD. In 2012, Gheorghiu was the guest of honor at a London Royal Opera House gala which was also attended by [[Elizabeth II]]. The Romanian soprano sang at the event, which was organized to raise funds for the Royal Opera House Foundation.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.romania-insider.com/two-romanians-perform-for-queen-elisabeth-ii-at-royal-opera-house-gala/|title=Two Romanians perform for Queen Elizabeth II at Royal Opera House gala |first=Romania|last=Insider|date=31 October 2012|publisher=}}</ref> She also sang at the [[Queen Beatrix]]'s Jubilee Gala in Amsterdam (2005), at the New Year's Eve Concert at [[Palais Garnier]] in Paris (2006), at the Met Summer Concert in [[Prospect Park (Brooklyn)|Prospect Park]], New York (2008), and at the Memorial Concert for [[Luciano Pavarotti]] in [[Petra]], where she also performed an unconventional duet of "[[Là ci darem la mano]]" from Mozart's ''[[Don Giovanni]]'' with [[Sting (musician)|Sting]] (2008).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.zimbio.com/photos/Sting/Angela+Gheorghiu|title=Sting Angela Gheorghiu Photostream|publisher=}}</ref>
In 2009, Gheorghiu was invited to honor [[Grace Bumbry]] during the 32nd Annual [[Kennedy Center Honors]], in Washington, DC. She performed "[[Vissi d'arte]]" from Puccini's ''Tosca'' in the presence of [[Barack Obama]].<ref>Torrance, Kelly Jane [http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2009/dec/07/kennedy-center-honorees-reflect-americas-diversity/?page=3 Kennedy Center honorees reflect America's diversity], ''The Washington Times'', December 7, 2009</ref>
In December 2000, Gheorghiu performed the title role in the film ''Tosca'', directed by Benoit Jacquot, together with [[Roberto Alagna]] and [[Ruggero Raimondi]].<ref>{{IMDb title|0240122|Tosca|(2001)}}</ref> One year later, in 2002, Gheorghiu interpreted Juliette in the movie ''Roméo et Juliette'', alongside Roberto Alagna and [[Tito Beltrán]], also released on DVD.<ref>{{IMDb title|0327118|Roméo et Juliet}}</ref>
In November 2010, Gheorghiu made her debut in [[Francesco Cilea]]'s ''[[Adriana Lecouvreur]]'', a new production of the Royal Opera House, Covent Garden. ''[[The Observer]]'' wrote, "It's hard to imagine anyone bettering Angela Gheorghiu in this part. Her voice, feather-light and creamy yet with a core of steel, matches the liquid way she moves on stage. She's a natural actress and made the improbable death scene heartbreakingly believable and her signature aria 'Poveri fiori' simply unforgettable."<ref>Pritchard, Stephen [https://www.theguardian.com/music/2010/nov/21/adriana-lecouvreur-cilea-tansy-davies The Observer], London, November 21, 2010</ref> ''The Telegraph'' wrote, "''Adriana'' is known as a nice, easy sing for ageing or challenged prima donnas (no difficult top notes, and a tame orchestra), so Gheorghiu, in her vocal prime, should have found it a doddle. But her first aria was bumpy and nervous, and she fudged the end of the second. Elsewhere, in duet and declamation, she often sang exquisitely."<ref>Christiansen, Rupert [https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/music/opera/8147350/Adriana-Lecouvreur-Royal-Opera-House-London-review.html ''The Daily Telegraph''], London, 19 November 2010</ref>
In July 2011, Gheorghiu sang the title role in ''Tosca'' at the Royal Opera House conducted by [[Antonio Pappano]], and the following September returned there for the revival of ''[[Faust (opera)|Faust]]'', which was broadcast live in cinemas all over the world. In April 2012, she appeared for the first time at the [[Teatro Colón]], Buenos Aires, in a concert of duets with Roberto Alagna.<ref>[http://www.bucharestherald.com/star-gossip/42-star-gossip/32210-angela-gheorghiu-to-perform-on-buenos-airescolon-teatro-stage-in-premiere-together-with-roberto-alagna Article in Bucharest Herald] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120414013241/http://www.bucharestherald.com/star-gossip/42-star-gossip/32210-angela-gheorghiu-to-perform-on-buenos-airescolon-teatro-stage-in-premiere-together-with-roberto-alagna |date=April 14, 2012 }}, 9 April 2012.</ref>
In February 2012, Gheorghiu was the special guest at the [[Vienna Opera Ball]], where she performed accompanied by conductor [[Georges Prêtre]] and the [[Vienna State Opera]] Orchestra.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://wien.orf.at/news/stories/2521250/|title=Glanz und Glamour beim Opernball |website=wien.ORF.at}}</ref>
In June 2012, Gheorghiu celebrated 20 years since her debut on the stage of the Royal Opera House, London, by performing in ''[[La bohème]]'' with Roberto Alagna. In July 2012, she held her first [[master class]] at the [[Georg Solti]] Accademia in [[Castiglione della Pescaia]], Italy. She returned to [[Tuscany]] for a second masterclass at the [[Georg Solti]] Accademia in 2016.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.georgsoltiaccademia.org/2016-gsa-summer/|title=2016 Bel Canto Masterclasses|date=8 September 2015|publisher=}}</ref> In November 2012 she returned to San Francisco Opera to perform in Puccini's ''Tosca''. In an interview<ref>{{cite web|url=http://kurier.at/kultur/buehne/angela-gheorghiu-warum-muss-sie-sterben/51.519.938|title=Angela Gheorghiu: "Warum muss sie sterben?"|first=|last=peter.jarolin|publisher=}}</ref> with ''[[Kurier]]'' from February 2014, Gheorghiu expressed interest in performing the role of Norma and in recording the role of Desdemona (Otello). Her most recent role debut was as Charlotte in Massenet's ''[[Werther]]'' in March 2015 at the [[Vienna State Opera]], to great critical acclaim.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://bachtrack.com/kritik-werther-gheorghiu-terzier-chaslin-wien-staatsoper-maerz-2015|title=Aufwühlender Seelenschmerz|website=bachtrack.com}}</ref> Gheorghiu also performed the role of Charlotte in August 2015 at the [[Salzburg Festival]] in a concert version with great success.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://diepresse.com/home/kultur/klassik/4800481/Festspiele_Werther-als-hoeherer-Naturbursch|title=Festspiele: Werther als höherer Naturbursch|publisher=}}</ref>
In July 2015, Gheorghiu made her debut at the [[Verbier Festival]] in [[Switzerland]] with guitarist [[Miloš Karadaglić]] in a special recital at The Église.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.classical-music.com/blog/truly-mountainous-event|title=A truly mountainous event |website=www.Classical-Music.com}}</ref>
In October 2015, Gheorghiu appeared for the first time ever in Australia, performing in two exceptional gala concerts at the [[Sydney Opera House]] and at Hammer Hall, [[Arts Centre Melbourne]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.limelightmagazine.com.au/live-reviews/review-angela-gheorghiu-4d-international|title=Review: Angela Gheorghiu (4D-International)|website=www.limelightmagazine.com.au}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://simonparrismaninchair.com/2015/10/14/an-evening-with-angela-gheorghiu-review-melbourne/|title=An Evening with Angela Gheorghiu review [Melbourne]|first=Simon|last=Parris|date=14 October 2015|publisher=}}</ref><ref>http://melbourne.eventful.com/events/angela-gheorghiu-/E0-001-086389822-9</ref> In November 2015, Gheorghiu performed at the Richard Tucker Opera Gala, "opera world’s most highly anticipated event of the season", at [[David Geffen Hall]], Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts, in [[New York City]]. The gala was broadcast on February 5, 2016 on [[PBS]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aboutlincolncenter.org/press-room/release/901?category_id=18|title=Press Release |publisher= Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts|website=www.aboutlincolncenter.org}}</ref> Gheorghiu also sang at the Richard Tucker Opera Gala in 1999.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tcm.com/tcmdb/title/477727/Richard-Tucker-Opera-Gala-Hosted-By-Placido-Domingo-The/|title=Richard Tucker Opera Gala Hosted By Placido Domingo, The 1999 Overview |website=Turner Classic Movies}}</ref> In November 2015, Gheorghiu sang at the Elena Obraztsova Opera Ball at [[Bolshoi Theatre]] in Moscow, Russia.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.alamy.com/stock-photo-moscow-russia-november-9-2015-romanian-soprano-angela-gheorghiu-attends-89660030.html|title= Romanian soprano Angela Gheorghiu attends a press conference on the Elena Obraztsova Opera Ball gala concert |first=Artyom |last=Geodakyan|website=Alamy.com|date=November 9, 2015|location=Moscow}}</ref> On the 29 November 2015, Gheorghiu held a humanitarian concert at the [[Romanian Athenaeum]] to raise funds for the victims of the [[Colectiv nightclub fire]]. The concert was organized in partnership with the George Enescu Philharmonic Orchestra and Choir and conductor Tiberiu Soare.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.citycompass.ro/events/romanian-soprano-angela-gheorghiu-holds-charity-concert-to-benefit-colectiv-fire-victims/|title=Romanian soprano Angela Gheorghiu holds concert to benefit Colectiv victims |website=www.citycompass.ro}}</ref> In December 2015, Gheorghiu sang together with [[Ramón Vargas]] and Ghiță Petean in a gala concert at [[Opéra de Monte-Carlo]]. All proceeds from this concert went to the Foundation established in the disappearance of Ramon Vargas's son, Eduardo, at the age of six ("Fund in memory of Eduardo Vargas").<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.romania-muzical.ro/stire/angela-gheorghiu-evolueaza-in-gala-de-opera-monte-carlo/1378591/47/5|title=Angela Gheorghiu evoluează în Gala de Operă Monte Carlo|website=Radio România Muzical}}</ref>
In 2016, Gheorghiu returned in the title role of Puccini's ''[[Tosca]]'' at the [[Royal Opera House]] and received great critical acclaim.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.express.co.uk/entertainment/theatre/634231/Opera-Review-Tosca-Royal-Opera-House|title=Opera Review: Tosca at the Royal Opera House|first=William|last=Hartston|date=13 January 2016|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ayoungertheatre.com/review-tosca-royal-opera-house/|title=Review: Tosca, Royal Opera House|date=11 January 2016|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/jan/11/royal-opera-house-tosca-gheorghiu-review-an-exceptionally-intelligent-evening|title=Tosca review – an exceptionally intelligent evening|first=Tim|last=Ashley|date=11 January 2016|publisher=|via=The Guardian}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://operabritanniauk.wordpress.com/2016/01/11/puccini-tosca-royal-opera-9th-january-2016/|title=Puccini : Tosca / Royal Opera, 9th January 2016|date=11 January 2016|publisher=}}</ref> Gheorghiu was scheduled to appear in 5 performances, but sang in a total of 7 performances.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.classicalsource.com/db_control/db_news.php?id=3494|title=ROH cast amendment: Angela Gheorghiu replaces Amanda Echalaz as Tosca |publisher=www.classicalsource.com}}</ref> She also returned as Tosca at the [[Wiener Staatsoper]] alongside [[Jonas Kaufmann]] and [[Bryn Terfel]]<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://angelagheorghiu.blogspot.ro/2015/04/angela-as-tosca-in-vienna-april-2016.html |title=Archived copy |access-date=2017-01-06 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170107100048/http://angelagheorghiu.blogspot.ro/2015/04/angela-as-tosca-in-vienna-april-2016.html |archive-date=2017-01-07 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> in April 2016. In September 2016, Gheorghiu performed in ''Tosca'' at the [[Staatsoper Berlin]] with "loud and prolonged ovation".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://seenandheard-international.com/2016/09/staatsopers-well-judged-tosca-makes-a-strong-impression/|title=Staatsoper’s Well Judged Tosca Makes a Strong Impression : Seen and Heard International|publisher=}}</ref>
2017 marks 25 years since Gheorghiu's international debut at the Royal Opera House in 1992.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bach-cantatas.com/Bio/Gheorghiu-Angela.htm|title=Angela Gheorghiu (Soprano) – Short Biography|website=www.bach-cantatas.com}}</ref> She performed there in ''[[Adriana Lecouvreur]]'' in February 2017.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.roh.org.uk/productions/adriana-lecouvreur-by-david-mcvicar|title=Adriana Lecouvreur – Productions – Royal Opera House|website=www.roh.org.uk}}</ref> In October of that year she made her house debut at the [[Teatro Massimo]] in [[Palermo]], again as Adriana Lecouvrer.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.teatromassimo.it/sala-stampa/comunicati/debutta-domani-adriana-lecouvreur-con-un-cast-di-star.html|title=Debutta domani Adriana Lecouvreur con un cast di star |website=Teatro Massimo Palermo|language=it|access-date=2018-09-30}}</ref>
== Awards and honors == Gheorghiu has recorded many recital albums and complete opera recordings and often appears on television and in concerts. Although Gheorghiu has not won an individual Grammy award, the [[EMI]] recording of [[Jules Massenet]]'s ''[[Manon]]'' with Gheorghiu in the title role won the 2001 [[Gramophone Award]] for "Best Opera Recording" and was nominated for "Best Opera Recording" in the 2002 [[Grammy Award]]s.<ref>[http://www.cnn.com/SPECIALS/2002/grammys/print.ballot3.html 2002 Grammy Nominees] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080912150334/http://www.cnn.com/SPECIALS/2002/grammys/print.ballot3.html |date=September 12, 2008 }}, Grammy Award Spotlight, [[CNN]]. Note that the Grammy awards recognize accomplishments by musicians from the previous year.</ref><ref>Paul Cutts [http://www.gramophone.co.uk/newsMainTemplate.asp?storyID=698&newssectionID=1 Alagna scores second Gramophone Awards success], ''[[Gramophone (magazine)|Gramophone]]'', October 19, 2001.</ref> The EMI recording of ''Tosca'' with Gheorghiu, Roberto Alagna and Ruggero Raimondi in the title roles brought her the [[Deutscher Schallplattenpreis]] award in 2002.<ref>[http://www.schallplattenkritik.de/component/content/article/66-bestenlisten-2002/295-bestenliste-1-2002 Deutscher Schallplattenpreis] Details about the prize</ref>
Gheorghiu has won 5 [[Gramophone Award]]s, most recently for [[Madama Butterfly]] in 2009.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gramophone.co.uk/musicians/artist/angela-gheorghiu-45673|title=Angela Gheorghiu|website=www.gramophone.co.uk}}</ref> She has also won ''Gramophone Awards'' in 1997 for [[Puccini]]'s [[La rondine]] (Record of the Year),<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.infoplease.com/ipa/A0301665.html|title=1997 Gramophone Awards|website=www.infoplease.com}}</ref> in 2000 for her album "Verdi Heroines" ([[Decca Records|Decca]]): Best Recital and Classic fM People's Choice Award in 2000 and 2001.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.infoplease.com/ipa/A0878680.html|title=2000 Gramophone Awards|website=www.infoplease.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.infoplease.com/ipa/A0886073.html|title=2001 Gramophone Awards|website=www.infoplease.com}}</ref>
In 2002, Gheorghiu won the [[Echo Klassik]] Award for "Female Singer of the Year".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.presseportal.de/pm/7840/360419|title=ZDF-Pressemitteilung / Preisträger "Echo Klassik 2002" bekannt gegeben / ZDF überträgt Galakonzert aus der Alten Oper Frankfurt am 13. Oktober 2002|publisher=}}</ref>
She also won [[Diapason d'Or]] Awards, Choc du Monde de la Musique in France, Cecilia Prize in Belgium, the Italian [[Musica e dischi]], Foreign Lyric Production Award, the United States Critics' Award.
Gheorghiu won the title of Female Artist of the Year at the [[Classic Brit Awards]] in 2001 and 2010.<ref>[http://www.classicalbrits.co.uk/artist/angela-gheorghiu Angela Gheorghiu won Classical Brit Award in 2010] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101231031132/http://www.classicalbrits.co.uk/artist/angela-gheorghiu |date=December 31, 2010 }}</ref>
In 2004, Gheorghiu won the [[Victoires de la musique classique]] award for the best opera recording for [[Bizet]]'s [[Carmen]] ([[EMI Classics]]).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.france3.fr/emissions/les-victoires-de-la-musique-classique/2004_443831|title=Les Victoires de la Musique Classique|website=www.france3.fr}}</ref>
She was honoured with "La Medaille Vermeille de la Ville de [[Paris]]" and she was appointed an Officier de l'[[Ordre des Arts et des Lettres]] and Chevalier de l'Ordre des Arts et Lettres by the French Ministry of Culture and by her native country [[Romania]].<ref>http://www.angelagheorghiu.com/biography.html</ref>
In December 2010, Gheorghiu was named [[Doctor Honoris Causa]] by the University of Arts in Iași (Romania)<ref>Victoria Cantir [http://www.ziaruldeiasi.ro/mozaic/angela-gheorghiu-si-costin-miereanu-vor-primi-titlul-de-doctor-honoris-causa-al-universitatii-de-arte-din-iasi~ni6st1 Ziarul de Iasi], 07.12.2010</ref> and the Star of Romania, the highest decoration given by the President of Romania.<ref>[http://www.legestart.ro/Decretul-921-2010-conferirea-Ordinului-National-Steaua-Romaniei-grad-Comandor-%28MzYxMDkx%29.htm?keepThis=true&TB_iframe=true&height=555&width=950 Monitorul Oficial] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111007063007/http://www.legestart.ro/Decretul-921-2010-conferirea-Ordinului-National-Steaua-Romaniei-grad-Comandor-%28MzYxMDkx%29.htm?keepThis=true&TB_iframe=true&height=555&width=950 |date=October 7, 2011 }}, Decretul 921 din 27 septembrie 2010 privind conferirea Ordinului National Steaua Romaniei in grad de Comandor</ref>
In October 2012, Gheorghiu received the [[Nihil Sine Deo]] royal decoration from [[King Michael I]], honoring her contribution to promoting Romanian culture in the world.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.familiaregala.ro/ro/familia-regala-astazi/ordine-si-medalii/nihil-sine-deo/|title=Decorația Regala Nihil Sine Deo|website=Familia Regala}}</ref>
In 2013, the DVD of [[Adriana Lecouvreur]] released by [[Decca Records|Decca]] where Gheorghiu plays the title role won at the [[International Classical Music Awards]] for Best DVD Performance.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.icma-info.com/winners-2013/|title=Winners 2013|publisher=}}</ref>
In October 2014, Gheorghiu received the honorary title of Doctor Honoris Causa from the [[Gheorghe Dima Music Academy]] in Cluj-Napoca. <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.clujulcultural.ro/soprana-angela-gheorghiu-a-devenit-de-astazi-doctor-honoris-causa-al-academiei-de-muzica/|title=Soprana Angela Gheorghiu a devenit de astăzi Doctor Honoris Causa al Academiei de Muzică - clujulcultural.ro|date=3 October 2014|publisher=}}</ref>
In 2014, Gheorghiu was included in the [[Gramophone Hall of Fame]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://revistamuzicala.radioromaniacultural.ro/?p=4572|title=ANGELA GHEORGHIU, RADU LUPU, DINU LIPATTI şi SERGIU CELIBIDACHE în Gramophone Hall of Fame! - Revista Muzicală Radio|website=revistamuzicala.radioromaniacultural.ro}}</ref> that celebrates the men and women whose contributions to classical music recording have proved the most influential and inspiring.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gramophone.co.uk/halloffame|title=Gramophone Hall of Fame|first=James|last=McCarthy|date=20 May 2013|website=www.gramophone.co.uk}}</ref>
In October 2015, Gheorghiu was awarded the European Cultural Award in a special gala ceremony in [[Dresden]], [[Germany]]<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.europaeische-kulturstiftung.com/verleihung.php |title=Archived copy |access-date=2017-01-06 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160725011236/http://www.europaeische-kulturstiftung.com/verleihung.php |archive-date=2016-07-25 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref>
==Gheorghiu at the Met and elsewhere== On occasion, Gheorghiu has had difficult relationships with opera house managements and directors. Some, but not all, of them have stemmed from her opposition to directors who, as she put it in an interview with ''[[ABC (newspaper)|ABC]]'' "want to express their own fantasies, forgetting about the characters. At times, she says, what they put on stage goes against both the story and the music."<ref>''"que quiere expresar sus fantasías, olvidándose de los personajes. A veces, lo que se representa en el escenario va en contra de la historia y de la música."'' in Susana Gaviña, [http://www.abc.es/hemeroteca/historico-18-05-2007/abc/Espectaculos/yo-tengo-el-control-en-la-opera-angela-gheorghiu-_-soprano_1633176191100.html «Yo tengo el control en la ópera»], ''[[ABC (newspaper)|ABC]]'', May 18, 2007. Retrieved 3 June 2008.</ref> She has attributed her outspokenness to her upbringing in Romania under the [[Totalitarianism|totalitarian]] regime of Nicolae Ceaușescu: <blockquote>"Because I grew up in a country where there was no possibility of having an opinion, it makes me stronger now. Lots of singers are frightened about not getting invited back to an opera house if they speak out. But I have the courage to be, in a way, revolutionary. I want to fight for opera, for it to be taken seriously. Pop music is for the body, but opera is for the soul."<ref>Warwick Thompson, [http://entertainment.timesonline.co.uk/tol/arts_and_entertainment/music/article1742639.ece Her serene highness], ''[[The Times]]'', May 4, 2007. Retrieved 3 June 2008.</ref></blockquote>
Gheorghiu had a problematic relationship with former [[Metropolitan Opera]] General Manager [[Joseph Volpe (opera manager)|Joseph Volpe]] after her debut there as Mimì in 1993. In 1996, Gheorghiu was cast as Micaela in a new production of [[Bizet]]'s ''[[Carmen]]'', opposite [[Waltraud Meier]] and [[Plácido Domingo]]. The production by [[Franco Zeffirelli]] called for Micaela to wear a blonde wig, which Gheorghiu disliked. When the Met toured the production in Japan in 1997, she refused to wear it on the first night to which Volpe famously declared, "The wig is going on, with you or without you" and replaced her with an understudy.<ref name=AT98>[[Anthony Tommasini|Tommasini, Anthony]] (April 4, 1998). [https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9F0CE3D8123AF937A35757C0A96E958260&pagewanted=all "Hesitating Celebrity Couple Loses a Met Opera Contract"]. ''[[The New York Times]]''. Retrieved 16 April 2011.</ref><ref>Fiedler, Johanna (2001). [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=cAYJAQAAMAAJ&q=Gheorghiu+wig+Volpe&dq=Gheorghiu+wig+Volpe ''Molto Agitato: The mayhem behind the music at the Metropolitan Opera'']. Doubleday, p. 299. {{ISBN|0-385-48187-X}}</ref>
She appeared at the Met again in 1998 for six performances of Gounod's ''[[Roméo et Juliette]]'' with her husband, tenor Roberto Alagna as Roméo. Volpe had planned to engage Gheorghiu in Violetta Valery for a new production of ''[[La traviata]]'', to premiere in November 1998 and directed by Zeffirelli. Alagna was to sing the role of Violetta's lover, Alfredo Germont. According to Volpe, Gheorghiu and Alagna argued with the staff and the director over production details and continually delayed signing the contract. They eventually signed their contracts, and faxed them to the Met one day past their deadline. Volpe refused to accept them. The production opened with [[Patricia Racette]] and [[Marcelo Álvarez]] as the lovers.<ref name=AT98 />
Despite these issues, Gheorghiu and Alagna returned to the Metropolitan Opera for five performances of Donizetti's ''[[L'elisir d'amore]]'' in 1999 and for four performances of ''[[Faust (opera)|Faust]]'' in 2003. Gheorghiu also performed at the Met as Liù in Puccini's ''[[Turandot]]'' in 2000; as Violetta in ''[[La traviata]]'' opposite [[Jonas Kaufmann]] in 2006 and 2007; as Amelia in Verdi's ''[[Simon Boccanegra]]'' in 2007; as Mimì in ''[[La bohème]]'' in 2008; as Magda in the 2008/2009 season in the ROH/SFO production of ''[[La rondine]]'', the Met's first performance of the opera since 1936; and for the 2009/2010 season she appeared as Violetta, replacing her previous engagement as Marie Antoinette in a rare revival of [[John Corigliano]]'s ''[[The Ghosts of Versailles]]'', which was replaced due to the recession.
In September 2007, Gheorghiu was dismissed from [[Lyric Opera of Chicago]]'s production of ''La bohème'' by General Manager William Mason, for missing rehearsals and costume fittings, and generally "unprofessional" behavior. Gheorghiu said in a statement that she had missed some rehearsals to spend time with her husband, who was singing at the Met in ''Roméo et Juliette'' and rehearsing for Puccini's ''[[Madama Butterfly]]'' and added, "I have sung ''Bohème'' hundreds of times, and thought missing a few rehearsals wouldn't be a tragedy. It was impossible to do the costume fitting at the same time I was in New York.<ref>[http://www.iht.com/articles/ap/2007/09/28/arts/NA-A-E-MUS-US-Opera-Gheorghiu-Fired.php "Lyric Opera of Chicago fires soprano Angela Gheorghiu"], Associated Press, via ''[[The International Herald Tribune]]'', September 28, 2007. Retrieved 3 June 2008.</ref>
Six weeks later, Gheorghiu made her debut at [[San Francisco Opera]] receiving favorable reviews for her Magda in that company's new production of ''La rondine''.<ref>Joshua Kosman, [http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2007/11/09/DDJLT8QN6.DTL "Gheorghiu's debut worth the wait in Opera's ''La rondine''"], ''San Francisco Chronicle'', November 9, 2007. Retrieved 3 June 2008.</ref><ref>Georgia Rowe, [http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_qn4176/is_20071113/ai_n21101016 "Angela Gheorghiu is the wind beneath the wings of ''La rondine''"], ''The Oakland Tribune'', November 13, 2007. Retrieved 3 June 2008</ref> The San Francisco Opera production originated with London's Royal Opera House, where it premiered on May 7, 2002 with Gheorghiu and Alagna as Magda and her lover Ruggero. It is one which she particularly admires: "When the curtain opened on ''La rondine'' at Covent Garden, the audience gasped and applauded. People want to dream. If directors want to do something new with operas, why not do something beautiful?"<ref>Robert Thicknesse, [http://entertainment.timesonline.co.uk/tol/arts_and_entertainment/article443639.ece?token=null&offset=12 The angel comes down to earth], ''The Times'', June 11, 2004. Retrieved 3 June 2008.</ref>
On December 31, 2008, Gheorghiu premiered the new production of ''La rondine'' at the Metropolitan Opera, together with Roberto Alagna, Marius Brenciu, [[Lisette Oropesa]] and Samuel Ramey. The opera was last performed at the house over 70 years ago. She received some favorable reviews for her Magda: "Gheorghiu embodies the part, as actress and singer, with her natural charisma."<ref>Fruehauf, Rosemarie, [http://epoch-archive.com/a1/en/us/lax/2009/01-Jan/15/B2_EET.pdf "The Met's ''La rondine'' Charms"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131021123917/http://epoch-archive.com/a1/en/us/lax/2009/01-Jan/15/B2_EET.pdf |date=2013-10-21 }}, ''The Epoch Times'', January 15–21, 2009</ref> The ''New York Times'' opinion was more mixed: "Vocally, both leads are somewhat disappointing. Ms. Gheorghiu, as Magda, sings with gleaming sound and wonderfully dusky colorings in the strong top register of her voice. But the earthy richness of her mid-range singing sometimes turns breathy, and her low voice is curiously weak."<ref>[[Anthony Tommasini|Tommasini, Anthony]] (January 1, 2009). [https://www.nytimes.com/2009/01/02/arts/music/02rond.html "Puccini and Operetta? He Does It His Way"]. ''[[The New York Times]]''. Retrieved 16 April 2011</ref>
In August 2009, Gheorghiu canceled all her scheduled 2010 Met performances of ''Carmen'', for "personal reasons".<ref>Walker, Tim, [https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/music/opera/6023289/Soprano-Angela-Gheorghiu-refuses-to-sing-in-New-Year.html "Soprano Angela Gheorghiu refuses to sing in New Year"], ''[[The Daily Telegraph|The Telegraph]]'', 13 August 2009. Accessed 10 October 2009</ref> It was to have been her first public performance of the title role (written for and normally sung by a [[mezzo-soprano]]). This was later attributed to her separation from her husband, Roberto Alagna, who was scheduled to sing opposite her.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://weblogs.baltimoresun.com/entertainment/classicalmusic/2009/10/operas_love_couple_roberto_ala.html|title=Welcome to my blog|first=Tim|last=Smith|publisher=}}</ref> She also cancelled other Met performances scheduled near the end of 2010. In March 2011 she cancelled all her scheduled performances of Gounod's ''Roméo et Juliette'' at the Met, citing illness. Only days later she cancelled all her performances in the scheduled new production of ''[[Faust]]'' during the Met's 2011/2012 season. According to her manager, "She felt uncomfortable in the concept". Peter Gelb, the Met's general manager, said that her frequent cancellations had become "an increasingly difficult problem for (the Met)." Gelb went on to say that, as of then, plans were still in place for Gheorghiu's return to the Met stage. He also said, "This has nothing to do with wigs.".<ref>Wakin, Daniel J.. [https://www.nytimes.com/2011/03/08/arts/music/angela-gheorghiu-cancels-her-faust-at-metropolitan-opera.html?ref=music "Gheorghiu Withdraws From ''Faust'' at Met"]. ''[[The New York Times]]'', March 7, 2011</ref>
Gheorghiu returned to the Met in December 2014 to perform to great critical acclaim<ref>{{cite web|url=http://observer.com/2014/12/winter-surprises-at-the-met-a-star-is-born-and-a-stunning-voice-returns/|title=Winter Surprises at the Met: A Star is Born and a Stunning Voice Returns|date=18 December 2014|publisher=}}</ref> as Mimì in ''La bohème'', opposite [[Michael Fabiano]].
Gheorghiu performed her first Met ''[[Tosca]]'' in the [[Luc Bondy]] production in the 2015/16 season<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.metopera.org/opera/tosca-puccini-tickets |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2015-03-15 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150324022054/http://www.metopera.org/opera/tosca-puccini-tickets |archivedate=2015-03-24 |df= }}</ref> with great reviews: "the famous "Vissi d'arte" was easily the most poignant moment of the night from every angle...At the climax of the aria, her voice soared through the theater in painful anguish and her final notes were held out with seemingly endless breath";<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.latinpost.com/articles/91741/20151103/metropolitan-opera-review-2015-16-tosca-angela-gheorghiu-rivets-complex.htm|title=Metropolitan Opera Review 2015-16- 'Tosca:' Angela Gheorghiu Rivets With Complex Portrayal of Title Role|first=Latin|last=Post|date=3 November 2015|publisher=}}</ref> "The color of her voice is gorgeous—her tone is smooth and full, mellow but with a hint of lemon";<ref>{{cite web|url=http://newyorkclassicalreview.com/2015/10/a-diva-brings-intimate-conviction-to-a-diva-in-mets-tosca/|title=New York Classical Review|website=newyorkclassicalreview.com}}</ref> "Her idiosyncratically alluring, sometimes maddening, always fascinating Floria Tosca inevitably became the evening’s unmissable raison d'être!".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://parterre.com/2015/10/30/veiled-threat/|title=Veiled threat|publisher=}}</ref>
==Personal life== [[File:Roberto Alagna Angela Gheorghiu Cannes.jpg|thumb|Angela Gheorghiu and Roberto Alagna at the [[2006 Cannes Film Festival]]]] Divorced from her first husband, Romanian engineer Andrei Gheorghiu,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.ie/entertainment/music/music-news/determined-diva-soprano-angela-gheorghiu-34429049.html|title=Determined diva: soprano Angela Gheorghiu|website=independent.ie|date=8 February 2016|accessdate=14 October 2018}}</ref> from whom she retained her surname, Gheorghiu married tenor [[Roberto Alagna]] in 1996. The couple have sung together often on stage and on studio recordings. She was once chosen the 74th "sexiest woman in the world" by the magazine ''[[FHM]]''.<ref>Ed Vulliamy, [http://music.guardian.co.uk/classical/story/0,,1973773,00.html Angela Gheorghiu and Roberto Alagna: A double act of arias and anger], ''[[The Observer]]'', December 17, 2006; [http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/comment/article673558.ece With a voice like that, she's allowed to be a nightmare], ''[[The Times]]'', June 11, 2006.</ref> In October 2009, Alagna said in an interview in ''[[Le Figaro]]'' that he and Gheorghiu had separated.<ref>Lutaud, Léna [http://www.lefigaro.fr/musique/2009/10/08/03006-20091008ARTFIG00663-roberto-alagna-et-angela-gheorghiu-se-separent-.php "Roberto Alagna et Angela Gheorghiu se séparent"], ''[[Le Figaro]]'', 8 October 2009. Accessed 8 October 2009</ref>
Following the separation, she declined to appear opposite Alagna in ''Carmen'' at the Metropolitan Opera in December 2009.<ref>Bernheimer, Martin [http://www.ft.com/cms/s/2/7aaf88fc-f953-11de-80dc-00144feab49a.html "Carmen"], ''[[Financial Times]]'', 4 January 2010. Accessed 7 January 2010</ref> The divorce, however, was called off in December 2009.<ref>[[Antena 3 (Romania)|Antena 3]]. [http://www.antena3.ro/life-show/cultura/soprana-angela-gheorghiu-nu-mai-divorteaza-video-87291.html "Soprana Angela Gheorghiu nu mai divorţează"] 12 December 2009 {{ro icon}}</ref> In a March 2011 interview with the ''[[Daily Express]]'' she stated that she and Alagna were back together, and they were seen together in March 2011 backstage at London's Royal Opera House where Alagna was performing in ''[[Aida]]''. She also stated in the interview that although she still wanted to sing separately from her husband for a while, she was looking forward to the day when they could retire together and have their own pets.<ref>Grant, Brigit. [http://www.express.co.uk/posts/view/234272/Diva-Angela-Gheorghiu-is-a-little-angelDiva-Angela-Gheorghiu-is-a-little-angelDiva-Angela-Gheorghiu-is-a-little-angelDiva-Angela-Gheorghiu-is-a-little-angel "Diva Angela Gheorghiu is a Little Angel"]. ''[[Daily Express]]'', March 13, 2011</ref><ref>Bucharest English Herald 14 Mar 2011 story – Angela Gheorghiu and her husband, tenor Roberto Alagna are back together</ref><ref>Alagna in an interview in the September 2011 Diapason</ref> Later that year, they jointly opened a Greek amphitheatre in the [[Qatar|Emirate of Qatar]].<ref>Townson, Peter (13 December 2011). [http://www.gulf-times.com/site/topics/article.asp?cu_no=2&item_no=475525&version=1&template_id=36&parent_id=16 "Cultural village amphitheatre opens with inspiring concert"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120114232559/http://www.gulf-times.com/site/topics/article.asp?cu_no=2 |date=2012-01-14 }}. ''[[Gulf Times]]''</ref> In June 2012, they sang together in two performances of ''La bohème'' at The Royal Opera House to commemorate the 20 years since they had met in the very same production. They also sang at a joint concert in Buenos Aires, and planned to perform together in ''Manon Lescaut'' and ''Adriana Lecouvreur'' in future seasons.<ref>Franini, Piera Anna (26 September 2010). [http://www.ilgiornale.it/news/spettacoli/gheorghiu-mio-periodo-zen-840820.html "Gheorghiu: è il mio periodo «zen»"]. ''[[Il Giornale]]''. Retrieved 7 January 2013 {{it icon}}.</ref> Gheorghiu said of their separation, "It was stupid of us to be apart."<ref>Smith, Julia Llewellyn (25 November 2011). [https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/music/opera/8786844/Opera-singer-Angela-Gheorghiu-says-of-her-marital-difficulties-with-Roberto-Alagna-It-was-stupid-of-us-to-be-apart.html "Opera singer Angela Gheorghiu says of her marital difficulties with Roberto Alagna: 'It was stupid of us to be apart'"]. ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]''. Retrieved 7 January 2013.</ref> However, in January 2013, she announced that they had agreed to divorce.<ref>Eden, Richard. (6 January 2013). [https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/celebritynews/9782692/Angela-Gheorghiu-and-Roberto-Alagna-bow-out.html "Opera's Posh & Becks, Angela Gheorghiu and Roberto Alagna, bow out"]. ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]''. Retrieved 7 January 2013.</ref>
Gheorghiu's younger sister, [[Elena Dan]], died in 1996 in an accident.<ref name="Matheopoulos, H. 1998 p.88">Matheopoulos, H., 'Diva: the New Generation' (Northeastern University Press, 1998), p.88</ref> She commented, "she was more than a sister to me... She was only a year younger. We were inseparable almost like twins, although she was blonde and green-eyed. She was another me. But, of course, it's worse for my mother. She is really very badly hit."<ref name="Matheopoulos, H. 1998 p.88"/> Elena Dan had married a doctor, Andrei Dan, and had a daughter called Ioana. After Andrei's death in 2001, Ioana was adopted by Gheorghiu and subsequently became a university student in the UK.

{{refimprove|date=January 2013}} {{Infobox royalty |name = Archduke John |image = Leopold Kupelwieser 001.jpg |caption = Portrait by [[Leopold Kupelwieser]], 1828 |succession = [[List of German monarchs|Imperial regent]] of [[German Empire (1848-49)]] |reign-type = In office |reign = 12 July 1848 – {{nowrap|20 December 1849}} |predecessor = [[Ferdinand I of Austria]] (President of the [[German Confederation]]) |successor = [[Francis Joseph I of Austria]] (President of the German Confederation) |house = [[House of Lorraine|House of Habsburg-Lorraine]] |father = [[Leopold II, Holy Roman Emperor]] |mother = [[Maria Luisa of Spain]] |birth_date = {{Birth date|1782|1|20|df=y}} |birth_place = [[Florence]], [[Grand Duchy of Tuscany]] |death_date = {{death date and age|1859|5|11|1782|1|20|df=y}} |death_place = [[Graz]], [[Duchy of Styria|Styria]], [[Austrian Empire]] |spouse = [[Anna Plochl|Anna Maria Josephine Plochl]] |issue = [[Franz, Count of Meran]] |place of burial = [[Schenna]] Castle, [[County of Tyrol|Tyrol]] |religion=[[Roman Catholic]] }} '''Archduke John of Austria''' ({{lang-de|Erzherzog Johann Baptist Joseph Fabian Sebastian von Österreich}}; 20 January 1782 – 11 May 1859), a member of the [[House of Lorraine|House of Habsburg-Lorraine]], was an [[Austrian Empire|Austrian]] [[field marshal]] and [[List of German monarchs|imperial regent]] (''Reichsverweser'') of the short-lived [[German Empire (1848/1849)|German Empire]] during the [[Revolutions of 1848 in the German states|Revolutions of 1848]]. ==Biography== John was born in [[Florence]], the thirteenth child of the Habsburg grand duke [[Leopold II, Holy Roman Emperor|Leopold of Tuscany]] and [[Maria Louisa of Spain]]. He was baptized with the name of John Baptist Joseph Fabian Sebastian,{{sfn|Schlossar|1878|p=319}} after the patron saint of the Tuscan capital. In 1790, Leopold succeeded his brother [[Joseph II, Holy Roman Emperor|Joseph II]] as [[Holy Roman Emperor]] and his family moved from the [[Grand Duchy of Tuscany]] to the [[Holy Roman Empire|Imperial]] court in Vienna. Only two years later, John's elder brother [[Francis II, Holy Roman Emperor|Francis II]] ascended the Imperial throne. [[File:Arciduca Giovanni d'Austria.jpg|thumb|left|Archduke John of Austria, {{circa|1799}}]] John's native language was [[Italian language|Italian]], he learned to speak [[French language|French]] and [[German language|German]] fluently. Educated by the Swiss historian [[Johannes von Müller]], he developed wide-ranging skills and interests, especially in the history and geography of the [[Alps|Alpine]] countries. ===Military service=== During the [[Napoleonic Wars]], John was given command of the [[Military history of Austria|Austrian army]] in September 1800, despite his personal reluctance to assume the position. He showed personal bravery in the [[War of the Second Coalition]], but his troops were crushed at the [[Battle of Hohenlinden]] on 3 December. Demoralized by defeat, the army nearly disintegrated in the subsequent retreat, which was only stopped by an armistice arranged on 22 December. After the [[Treaty of Lunéville|Peace of Lunéville]] in 1801, Archduke John was made General Director of the Engineering and Fortification Service, and later commander of the [[Theresian Military Academy]] in [[Wiener Neustadt]]. In the [[War of the Third Coalition]], John again fought the [[First French Empire|French]] and [[Electorate of Bavaria|Bavarian]] forces. From 1805 he directed an able defence of several [[County of Tyrol|Tyrolean]] passes against the French and was awarded the Commander Cross of the [[Military Order of Maria Theresa]]. However, according to the [[Peace of Pressburg (1805)|Peace of Pressburg]], Austria had to cede Tyrol and [[Vorarlberg]] to Bavaria. John remained obliged to Tyrol and maintained friendly contact with Baron [[Joseph Hormayr, Baron zu Hortenburg|Joseph Hormayr]] who forged a resistance movement against the Bavarian occupation. In 1808, John pressed for the creation of Tyrolean [[Landwehr]] forces based on the success of the [[Prussian Army|Prussian Landwehr]], which played a vital role in the [[Tyrolean Rebellion]] led by [[Andreas Hofer]]. At the commencement of the [[War of the Fifth Coalition]] in 1809 he became commander of the Army of [[Inner Austria]], fighting against the French forces of [[Eugène de Beauharnais]] in Italy. Under his command were the VIII Armeekorps led by [[Albert Gyulai]] and the IX Armeekorps headed by Albert's brother [[Ignaz Gyulai]]. After winning a significant victory at the [[Battle of Sacile]] on 16 April 1809, his army advanced almost to [[Verona]]. Having detached forces to besiege [[Venice]] and other fortresses, John's army was soon outnumbered by Eugène's heavily reinforced host. Worse, news of the Austrian defeat at the [[Battle of Eckmühl]] reached him and compelled him to order a retreat. Before withdrawing, he fought off Franco-Italian attacks at the [[Battle of Caldiero (1809)|Battle of Caldiero]] between 27 and 30 April. Attempting to blunt the Franco-Italian pursuit, he stood to fight on 8 May and was beaten at the [[Battle of Piave River (1809)|Battle of Piave River]]. Trying to defend the entire border, he sent Ignaz Gyulai to defend [[Ljubljana]] (Laibach) in [[Duchy of Carniola|Carniola]], while holding [[Villach]] in [[Duchy of Carinthia|Carinthia]] with his own forces. Eugène's pursuit overran the frontier defenses at the [[Battle of Tarvis (1809)|Battle of Tarvis]] and wrecked a column of hoped-for reinforcements at the [[Battle of Sankt Michael]]. Forced to flee northeast into [[Kingdom of Hungary|Hungary]], John offered battle again but was defeated at [[Battle of Raab|Raab]] on 14 June 1809. Ordered to join his brother [[Archduke Charles, Duke of Teschen|Archduke Charles]] at the [[Battle of Wagram]] on 5 and 6 July, John's small army arrived too late to avert an Austrian defeat. His brother criticized him for tardiness. After the conclusion of the campaign, John again evolved plans for a widespread rebellion. However, upon the [[Treaty of Schönbrunn]] Austrian policies under Minister [[Klemens von Metternich]] sought a rapprochement to France. John's friend Baron Hormayr and other conspirators were arrested, the archduke himself effectively was sidelined and retired to his estates in [[Scheiblingkirchen-Thernberg|Thernberg]]. ===Post military=== [[File:Anna Plochl1.jpg|thumb|{{Interlanguage link multi|Anna Plochl|de}}]] [[File:Proklamation-Reichsverweser-1848.png|thumb|upright|John's proclamation to the German people of July 15, 1848 after provisionally taking central control]] [[File:Archduke John of Austria 1848 Frankfurt Br.- Medal, obverse.jpg|left|thumb|Election of Erzherzog Johann von Österreich 1848 as Imperial Regent (Reichsverweser) by the Frankfurt Parliament. Medal by [[:de:Carl Radnitzky|Karl Radnitzky]], obverse.]] [[File:Archduke John of Austria 1848 Frankfurt Br.- Medal, reverse.jpg|left|thumb|Election of Erzherzog Johann von Österreich 1848 as Imperial Regent (Reichsverweser) by the Frankfurt Parliament. Medal by Karl Radnitzky, reverse, showing the [[Double-headed eagle|German double-headed Imperial Eagle]].]] John, tired of warfare, turned away from the military and developed a great interest for nature, technology and agriculture. He collected [[minerals]] and was active as an [[alpinist]] and [[hunter]] in the [[Duchy of Styria]]. In his early days Archduke Johann and his brother [[Archduke Louis of Austria|Louis]] had the habit of travelling to France, where the latter married [[Castle of Boisclaireau|Madame de Gueroust]]. In 1815, on his visit to the [[United Kingdom]], John received a ''Doctor honoris causa'' degree from the [[University of Edinburgh]].{{sfn|Schlossar|1878|p=319}} In the history of Styria, he is remembered as a great modernizer and became an important figure of identification for Styrians. His proximity to the people is given evidence to by his many contacts with the common man, by wearing the local [[Tracht]], the ''Steireranzug'', and by collecting and promoting the material and spiritual culture of the country. In 1811, he founded the [[Landesmuseum Joanneum|Joanneum Museum]] in [[Graz]] and the predecessor of [[Graz University of Technology]]. Some other foundations were initiated by him, such as the Styrian State Archive 1817, the ''Steiermärkisch-Ständische Montanlehranstalt'', which was founded in 1840 in Vordernberg and later became the [[University of Leoben]], the Styrian Society for Agriculture 1819, the Mutual Fire Insurance, the Styrian Building Society, the ''Landesoberrealschule'' in 1845 and the Society for Styrian History in 1850. His routing of the [[Austrian Southern Railway]] from [[Vienna]] to [[Triest]] over the [[Semmering Pass]] and through the [[Mur River|Mura]] and [[Mürz]] valleys to Graz is particularly notable. The inheritance of his maternal uncle Duke [[Albert Casimir, Duke of Teschen|Albert Casimir of Teschen]] enabled him to acquire a [[tin]] factory in Krems near [[Voitsberg]] and coal mines near [[Köflach]], thereby he also became an industrialist. In 1840, he bought the [[Stainz]] dominion, where he was also freely elected as mayor in 1850. He was already the lord of the Brandhof manor in [[Mariazell]]. In 1829, he married {{Interlanguage link multi|Anna Plochl|de}} (1804-1885), the daughter of Jakob Plochl, [[postmaster]] of [[Bad Aussee|Aussee]], and his wife Maria Anna Pilz, during a nocturnal ceremony in Brandhof. By this [[morganatic marriage]], John was excluded from succession to the throne. Emperor Francis elevated Anna to a "Baroness of Brandhofen" in 1834 and in 1839 she gave birth to a son, [[Franz, Count of Meran|Franz]], the only child from the marriage. His descendants were styled "Counts of Meran" and "Barons of Brandhofen", Proprietors of Stainz and Brandhofen. John was also a passionate mountaineer in the [[Eastern Alps]] and attempted to be the first to climb the [[Großvenediger]]. For that reason, the Erzherzog-Johann-Hütte (''Adlersruhe'') at the [[Grossglockner]], and the [[Nigritella|Archduke John's Vanilla Orchid]] (''Nigritella rubra'' subsp. ''archiducis-joannis''), an [[orchid]] growing on mountain meadows, are named after him. ===Imperial regent=== Even though Johann did not consider himself a [[Liberalism in Germany|liberal]], he promoted some liberal ideas. He was often in conflict with the Habsburg court, especially because of his morganatic marriage, though he never openly rebelled. He had earned great recognition in the Styrian lands, moreover he gained general acceptance by his jovial manners and his marriage with a middle-class woman. Upon the [[German revolutions of 1848–49|March Revolution of 1848]], the [[Frankfurt Parliament]] discussed the appointment of an all-[[German Confederation|German]] government replacing the [[Federal Convention (German Confederation)|Federal Convention]]. On a proposal by the liberal politician [[Heinrich von Gagern]], the assembly on 28 June 1848 voted for the establishment of a central authority (''[[Provisorische Zentralgewalt]]'') and on the next day a broad majority elected Archduke John [[regent]] of the realm (''Reichsverweser''). Archduke John accepted the nomination as [[head of state|head]] of the short-lived [[German Empire (1848/1849)|German Empire]] and on 12 July 1848 the delegates of the Federal Convention, in response to public pressure, ceded their powers to him. On July 15, he appointed the ministers [[Anton von Schmerling]], [[Johann Gustav Heckscher]] and Eduard von Peucker to office, completed by Prince [[Carl, 3rd Prince of Leiningen|Carl of Leiningen]] as minister president and [[head of government]]. Nevertheless, his political office did not offer many opportunities, though all laws had to be signed by him. First attempts by the government to obtain supreme command of the [[German Federal Army]] faced entrenched resistance from the member states. To strengthen support, the left-wing politician [[Robert von Mohl]] joined the Leiningen Cabinet on August 9. Leiningen himself resigned on September 6, after the Frankfurt assembly rejected to ratify the armistice of Malmö, signed by [[Kingdom of Prussia|Prussia]] during the [[First Schleswig War]]. Minister Anton von Schmerling acted as head of government, until from November 1848 the cabinet gradually lost the support of the centrist [[Casino faction]] and finally its majority in parliament. Schmerling was forced to resign and on December 17, Archduke John had to appoint Heinrich von Gagern new minister president, though he opposed his '[[Lesser Germany|Lesser German]]' ideas. Archduke John did not take part in the draft of the [[Frankfurt Constitution]], which was adopted on 28 March 1849 after lengthy negotiations led by Gagern, and he pronounced against the strong position of [[Kingdom of Prussia|Prussia]]. Determined to resign, he was once more turned over by the ministers. When in April 1849 King [[Frederick William IV of Prussia]] disappointed Gagern's hopes and openly rejected the Constitution, Archduke John remained passive and Gagern handed in his resignation on May 10. John insisted that he would exert central authority out of a sense of obligation, nevertheless he departed for a prolonged stay at the health resort of [[Bad Gastein]]. After the final failure of the March Revolution, he finally resigned from his office on 20 December 1849. When Archduke Johann came back to Frankfurt on a visit in 1858, he openly regretted the failure of the German unification. He died in 1859 in Graz, where a fountain erected in his honour (''illustration'') dominates the central square. He is buried in [[Schenna]] near [[Meran]]. [[Commander of the Order of the British Empire|CBE]] [[Order of Ikhamanga|OIS]] (4 October 1931 – 19 November 2011)<ref name="Cap">{{cite book |title=If The Cap Fits |last=Bateman |first=Colin |authorlink= |coauthors= |year=1993 |publisher=Tony Williams Publications |location= |isbn=1-869833-21-X |page=52 |pages= |url=}}</ref> was an [[England cricket team|England]] international cricketer of South African [[Cape Coloureds|Cape Coloured]] background, whose potential selection by England for the scheduled 1968–69 tour of [[apartheid]]-era South Africa caused the [[D'Oliveira affair]]. Nicknamed "Dolly",<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://uk.eurosport.yahoo.com/19112011/58/basil-d-oliveira-dies-aged-80.html|title=Yahoo UK & Ireland - Sports News {{!}} Live Scores {{!}} Results|website=Yahoo Sports|language=en-GB|access-date=2018-10-18}}</ref> D'Oliveira played [[county cricket]] for [[Worcestershire County Cricket Club|Worcestershire]] from 1964 to 1980, and appeared for England in 44 [[Test cricket|Test matches]] and four [[One Day International]]s between 1966 and 1972.
==Early life== Born into a religious [[Catholic Church|Catholic]] family of [[Indian-Portuguese]] descent in [[Signal Hill (Cape Town)|Signal Hill]], [[Cape Town]],<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/2011/11/27/sports/cricket/basil-doliveira-a-symbol-for-cricket-and-for-equality-dies-at-80.html Obituary], ''New York Times'', 27 November 2011</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cricketcountry.com/articles/basil-d-rsquo-oliveira-the-man-who-triggered-the-international-cricket-boycott-of-south-africa-31689|title=Basil D’Oliveira: The man who triggered the international cricket boycott of South Africa|last=Sengupta|first=Arunabha|publisher=Cricket County|date=4 October 2013|accessdate=2015-03-20}}</ref> as a boy he would make his way down to the [[Newlands Cricket Ground]] in Cape Town, and climb the trees outside to watch the games.<ref name=BBC15804126/>
D'Oliveira captained South Africa's national non-white cricket team, and also played [[Association football|football]] for the non-white national side.<ref name="cricpro">{{cite web|url=http://www.cricinfo.com/link_to_database/PLAYERS/ENG/D/DOLIVEIRA_BL_01001283/|title=Player Profile: Basil D'Oliveira|last=Thicknesse|first=John|work=CricInfo|publisher=ESPN|accessdate=2009-06-11}}</ref>
==Career== With the support of [[John Arlott]], and the members and supporters of St Augustine's Cricket Club in Cape Town, he emigrated to England in 1960, where the journalist [[John Kay (cricket journalist)|John Kay]] found him a place in his [[Central Lancashire Cricket League|Central Lancashire League]] team of [[Middleton Cricket Club|Middleton]].<ref name="Cap"/> D'Oliveira noted his surprise at seeing white people doing menial work, and waiting on him in restaurants.<ref>http://www.hinduonnet.com/thehindu/thscrip/print.pl?file=20050625006302200.htm&date=tss2826/&prd=tss&</ref> He joined the [[first-class cricket|first-class]] county team [[Worcestershire County Cricket Club]] in 1964, and became a British citizen.<ref>{{cite ODNB|author=Rob Steen|title=D'Oliveira, Basil Lewis (1931?–2011)|date= Jan 2015 |id= 104335|url=http://www.oxforddnb.com/public/dnb/104335.html}}</ref>
In 1966 he was selected for the [[England cricket team]] as an [[all-rounder]] to face the West Indians in the second Test. He made a solid debut, scoring 27 before being run out, and returning bowling figures of 1 for 24 and 1 for 46 in 39 overs. In the third Test he scored 76 and 54, while capturing 2 wickets for 51 and 2 for 77 at [[Trent Bridge]]; though the West Indies cantered to a 139-run victory. He contributed a fighting 88 in the fourth Test at [[Headingley Cricket Ground|Headingley]], although England once again lost, by an innings and 55 runs. D'Oliveira was quietly efficient in the final Test as England turned the tables on the West Indies, winning by an innings and 34 runs to lose the series 3-1. Against India he hit 109 in the first Test where England won by six wickets and went on to win the series 3-0. Facing Pakistan he hit fifties in both innings of the first Test, in a series that England won 2-0.<ref>http://www.safrica.info/about/sport/greats/doliveira.htm</ref> He was one of the [[Wisden Cricketers of the Year]] for 1967.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.espncricinfo.com/ci/content/story/154547.html|title=Basil D'Oliveira|work=Cricinfo|access-date=2018-10-17}}</ref>
Next up was an away series against the West Indies, early in 1968. D'Oliveira didn't turn in his best showing in the five matches, scoring only 137 runs at an average of 27.4. He did a lot of bowling, but picked up only three wickets, even though he was economical. Once back in England, it was time for a five-Test Ashes series. The Aussies crushed England by 159 runs in first Test as England crumbled in their second innings, despite D'Oliveira's top scoring effort of 87 not out. He was then dropped for the subsequent three Tests. He was recalled by the selectors for the final Test at the Oval, and 158 runs in the first innings against Australia seemed to have guaranteed his place in the side to play the 1968–69 Test series in South Africa.<ref name="Cap"/> He was left out of the touring party under the pretext that his bowling would not be effective in his native country.
He was selected in June 1969 to face the West Indies, this time in a three-Test series. He followed that with a three-match series against New Zealand and then a seven-Test Ashes series in Australia, in which he scored 369 runs at an average of 36.9, including 117 in the fifth Test at the MCG.
England then went to New Zealand for two Tests, with D'Oliveira scoring 100 in the first one and 58 and five in the second. Pakistan next visited England in 1971, and D'Oliveira enjoyed a fine series with the bat, making 241 runs at an average of 60.25. He was below par in the three-Test series against India that followed, but was in better form for the visit of Australia in June 1972.
D'Oliveira completed his career having played 41 Tests. He scored 2484 runs at an average of 40.06, with five centuries and 15 fifties. He also captured 47 wickets at 39.55.
==Playing style and personality== D'Oliveira was a successful batsman with a low backlift and powerful strokes.<ref name="Cap"/> He was also a tough competitor. When he toured [[English cricket team in Australia in 1970–71|Australia in 1970–71]] on the night after they won the series 2–0 he pushed his forefinger into the chest of every Australian he met, saying "We stuffed you."<ref name="snow">{{cite book |title=Cricket Rebel |last=Snow |first=John | authorlink =John Snow (cricketer)|year=1976 |publisher=Hamlyn |location= |isbn=0-6003-1932-6 |page=95}}</ref>
Wanting to play international cricket, D'Oliveira was somewhat cagey about his date of birth. After his death, journalist [[Pat Murphy (sports journalist)|Pat Murphy]] with whom he collaborated on his autobiography stated:<ref name=BBC15804126/> {{cquote|Basil had to lie about his age because he thought if they realised how old he was they would not pick him for England. So he came down from born in 1935 at that time, solidifying his place in the team as 1933 born and when I wrote his book in 1980 he finally conceded he was born in 1928. So by my calculation he was 38 when he first played for England in 1966 and 83 when he died.}}
==The D'Oliveira Affair== {{main|D'Oliveira affair}} South African cricket officials in 1968 realised that the inclusion of D'Oliveira in the England squad would lead to the cancellation of the tour, and probable exclusion of South Africa from Test cricket. This exerted pressure on the [[Marylebone Cricket Club]] (MCC) hierarchy leading to the decision not to pick him, which was felt by opponents of apartheid to be a way of keeping cricket links with South Africa open. There was dissent in the press to this course of events and when [[Warwickshire County Cricket Club|Warwickshire's]] [[Tom Cartwright]] was ruled out because of injury, D'Oliveira was called up into the squad.<ref name="Cap"/> South African prime minister [[B. J. Vorster]] had already made it clear that D'Oliveira's inclusion was not acceptable, and despite many negotiations the tour was cancelled; South Africa was excluded from Test cricket for 22 years. This was seen as a [[wiktionary:Watershed|watershed]] in the [[sporting boycott of apartheid South Africa]].<ref>{{cite book|title=The Politics of South African Cricket |author= Jon Gemmell|year= 2004|publisher=Routledge (UK)|url=https://books.google.com/books?visbn=0-7146-5346-2&id=CTIZdi9DjBQC&pg=PA146&lpg=PA146&dq=%22Basil+D%27Oliveira%22&ie=ISO-8859-1&output=html|isbn=0-7146-5346-2 }}</ref> The D'Oliveira Affair had a massive impact in turning international opinion against the apartheid regime in South Africa. It prompted changes in South African sport and eventually in society. The events of 1968 were dramatized on BBC Radio 4 in April 2009 in a play by Christopher Douglas entitled ''Dolly''.<ref> {{Cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b00jngcx|title=BBC Radio 4 - Afternoon Drama, Christopher Douglas - Dolly|website=BBC|language=en-GB|access-date=2018-10-17}} </ref>
==Legacy== In 2000, he was nominated as one of 10 South African cricketers of the century, despite not having played for South Africa.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/cricket/3818857.stm|title=D'Oliveira exposed apartheid disgrace|last=Gough|first=Martin|date=29 November 2004|work=BBC News Online|publisher=BBC|accessdate=2009-06-11}}</ref> In 2004, a perpetual trophy was struck for Test series between England and [[South Africa national cricket team|South Africa]], and named the [[Basil D'Oliveira Trophy]]. In 2005, he was awarded a [[Order of the British Empire|CBE]] in the [[British honours system|Queen's Birthday Honours]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/cricket/4078158.stm|title=D'Oliveira 'proud' to get honour |date=10 June 2005|work=BBC News Online|publisher=BBC|accessdate=2009-06-11}}</ref> In the same year, a stand at [[New Road, Worcester]], was named in his honour.
In 1980 after the end of his playing career, he wrote an autobiography with the BBC's [[Pat Murphy (sports journalist)|Pat Murphy]], titled ''Time to Declare''. In it, he stated for the first time that he was glad that the proposed South African cricket tour to England in 1970 was called off, for fear of public disturbances.<ref name=BBC15804126>{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/cricket/15804126.stm | work=BBC News | title=D'Oliveira was a hero - Murphy | date=19 November 2011}}</ref> In 2004, journalist [[Peter Oborne]] wrote a biography entitled ''Basil D'Oliveira: Cricket and Conspiracy'' ({{ISBN|0-3167-2572-2}}), which was awarded the [[William Hill Sports Book of the Year]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/cricket/4052663.stm |title=Book on D'Oliveira wins award |work=[[BBC News]] |date=29 November 2004 |accessdate=201-11-26}}</ref> and was accompanied by [[Paul Yule]]'s RTS award-winning documentary ''Not Cricket—The Basil D'Oliveira Conspiracy.''<ref>{{BBC programmes|b0074qcq|The Basil D'Oliveira Conspiracy}}</ref><ref>{{imdb title|422843|Not Cricket: The Basil d'Oliveira Conspiracy (2004)}}</ref>
==Personal life== He was married to Naomi, and their son [[Damian D'Oliveira]] also played first-class cricket for Worcestershire, while his younger brother [[Ivan D'Oliveira|Ivan]] played briefly for [[Leicestershire County Cricket Club|Leicestershire]].<ref name="cricpro" /> His grandson [[Brett D'Oliveira]] is currently contracted with Worcestershire and made his debut for the county in 2011.
==Death== D'Oliveira had [[Parkinson's disease]] in later life.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://basildoliveira.com/about/family/naomis-story/|title=Naomi’s Story|accessdate=2011-11-04}}</ref> He died aged 80 in England, on 19 November 2011.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.espncricinfo.com/england/content/story/541152.html |title=England news: Basil D'Oliveira dies aged 80 | England Cricket News |publisher=ESPN Cricinfo |date= |accessdate=2011-11-19}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sport24.co.za/Cricket/Basil-dOliveira-passes-away-20111119 |title=Basil d'Oliveira dies: Sport: Cricket |publisher=Sport24.co.za |date= |accessdate=2011-11-19}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/cricket/15803140.stm|title=England legend D'Oliveira dies|publisher=news.bbc.co.uk |date= 19 November 2011|accessdate=2011-11-19}}</ref>
A farewell for D'Oliveira was written on the last 2011 issue of ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' magazine by [[Trevor Manuel]], [[South Africa's Minister in the Presidency for National Planning]]. It highlights the personal successes of the cricket player, together with the impact he had on South African sport and society.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.time.com/time/specials/packages/article/0,28804,2101745_2102136_2102479,00.html | work=Time | title=Person Of The Year 2011 | date=2011-12-14}}</ref>
In September 2018 he was posthumously awarded the Freedom of the City of Worcester in recognition of his contribution to the city. The award was accepted by his son Shaun at a ceremony in the Guildhall in Worcester on 14 September 2018.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.worcester.gov.uk/news-alerts/-/blogs/cricket-legend-basil-d-oliveira-to-receive-posthumous-freedom-of-city|title=Cricket legend Basil D'Oliveira to receive posthumous Freedom of City|date=2018-09-07|accessdate=2018-09-15}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-hereford-worcester-45535246|title=Basil D'Oliveira awarded freedom of Worcester|date=2018-09-15|accessdate=2018-09-15}}</ref>

'''Estelle Betty Manyolo''' (born 1938) is a [[Uganda]]n painter and printmaker.
Manyolo, a [[Baganda|Muganda]] and one of ten children, studied art at the School of Fine Art at [[Makerere College]]. Later in her career she worked as an artist for Uganda's Department of Health. Several of her linocut prints, along with an oil painting, were exhibited through the [[Harmon Foundation]] beginning in 1961; her work was also included in the Smithsonian Institution Traveling Exhibit of Contemporary African Printmakers from 1966 until 1968.<ref name="Brown1966">{{cite book|author=Evelyn S. Brown|title=Africa's Contemporary Art and Artists: A Review of Creative Activities in Painting, Sculpture, Ceramics, and Crafts of More Than 300 Artists Working in the Modern Industrialized Society of Some of the Countries of Sub-Saharan Africa|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=EeArAAAAMAAJ|year=1966|publisher=Published and distributed by the Division of Social Research and Experimentation] Harmon Foundation}}</ref> Stylistically her work is reminiscent of [[cubism]], and is informed by a knowledge of Western art.<ref name="Donahue1979">{{cite book|author=Benedict Donahue|title=The Cultural Arts of Africa|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=SrqfAAAAMAAJ|year=1979|publisher=University Press of America|isbn=978-0-8191-0845-6}}</ref>

Siddharth Birla|otherfamilies =|distinctions =|traditions = [[Hindu]]|heirlooms =|estate =|meaning =|footnotes =|colour = powderblue|homepage = {{URL|http://www.ckbirlagroup.com/}}}} The '''Birla family''' is a family connected with the industrial and social history of India.{{cite web |url=http://www.adityabirla.com |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-11-29 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111129203833/http://www.adityabirla.com/ |archivedate=2011-11-29 |df= }}{{cite web|url=http://www.ckbirlagroup.com|title=CK Birla Group - Birla Companies - Family - US$1.6 billion diversified conglomerate that has a history of enduring relationships with renowned global companies.|website=www.ckbirlagroup.com|accessdate=9 July 2017}}{{cite web|url=http://www.business-standard.com/article/specials/yash-birla-s-business-comes-under-stress-114021701657_1.html|title=Yash Birla's business comes under stress|first=Dev Chatterjee & Sharleen|last=D'souza|date=17 February 2014|publisher=|accessdate=9 July 2017|via=Business Standard}} ==Foundations== The Birla family belongs to the [[Maheshwari]] subcaste of the [[Vaishya]] (trader) caste, and are [[Marwari people|Marwari]] since they hail from the [[Marwad]] region of present-day [[Rajasthan]]. Specifically, the family originates from the town of [[Pilani]] in the [[Shekhawati]] region lying between Marwad. ===Shiv Narayan Birla=== In Pilani during the early 19th century lived Seth Shobharam, grandson of Seth Bhudharmal, a local tradesman of modest means.Maheshwari Jati Ka Itihas, Maheshwari History Office, Bhanpura, Birla, June 1940, p. 183–190{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=pDlj7rwlDK0C&pg=PT684&lpg=PT684&dq=birla+daughters&source=bl&ots=c8DJbj8f7J&sig=iLvCokhf2N03_-OBQhAlHW6X5dM&hl=en&sa=X&ei=Q1JJVa28AoiZyATZ54GQCQ&ved=0CDUQ6AEwBDge#v=onepage&q=birla+daughters&f=false|title=Brushes With History|first=Krishna Kumar|last=Birla|date=17 April 2009|publisher=Penguin UK|accessdate=9 July 2017|via=Google Books}} It was his son, Seth Shiv Narayana (1840–1909), who first ventured outside Pilani. At this time, Ahmedabad was the railhead which serviced trade from a large region of northwest India. Goods (mainly cotton) would be brought from the hinterland to the city and sent from there by train to Bombay for export to England and other countries. Several cotton ginning units were also set up in Ahmedabad, to clean the cotton before shipment to England. Shiv Narayana Birla was one of the early Indian traders to participate in this cotton trade. Later, Britain vigorously fostered the trade of opium with China and developed the cultivation of poppy in India. The [[Ratlam]]-[[Mandsaur]] region (not far from Ahemdabad) became prime poppy cropland due to suitable soil and climate. Shiv Narayan Birla and his adopted son, Baldeo Das Birla, made an enormous fortune by trading opium with China, and this formed the basis of the family's fortune. With growing wealth and increasing confidence, Shiv Narayana Birla moved up the value chain and began chartering cargo ships in partnership with other Marwadi tradesmen to trade opium with China, thus by-passing British middlemen. To facilitate this, he moved to Bombay in 1863. ===Baldeo Das Birla=== Shiv Narain Birla had one overwhelming sorrow in his life: he had no children. By the early 1880s, Shiv narayan (Narain) had passed on the baton of his business interests to his adopted son, Baldeo Das Birla, established Shivnarayan Baldevdas, a trading house based in Bombay. His son, Baldeo Das Birla moved to Calcutta set up Baldevdas Jugalkishor in 1887. Baldeo Das was succeeded by four sons {{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Qhe3-G5aBkg|title=The story of the Birla empire by Talveen Singh- Part I|first=|last=Aditya Birla Group|date=31 May 2011|publisher=|accessdate=9 July 2017|via=YouTube}}– Jugal Kishore, Rameshwar Das, [[Ghanshyam Das Birla|Ghanshyam Das]] and Braj Mohan.[http://www.icmrindia.org/casestudies/catalogue/Business%20Strategy3/BSTA034.htm The Birla Family Crisis - Case Studies, Case Study in Business, Management|Case Studies] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140714221045/http://www.icmrindia.org/casestudies/catalogue/Business%20Strategy3/BSTA034.htm |date=July 14, 2014 }}{{cite web|url=http://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/battle-for-m.p.-birla-fortune-icai-indicts-lodhas/1/175181.html|title=Battle for Billions: Birlas vs Lodhas|publisher=|accessdate=9 July 2017}}{{cite web|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/life-style/books/What-keeps-the-Marwaris-thriving/articleshow/35380786.cms|title=What keeps the Marwaris thriving? - Times of India|publisher=|accessdate=9 July 2017}} Baldeo Das was awarded the Raibahadur title in 1917. In 1920 he retired from business and started living in Banares pursuing religious studies. In 1925 he was awarded the title of "Raja" by the government of Bihar and Orissa.Industrial Entrepreneurship of Shekhawati Marwaris, D.K. Taknet, Kumar Prakashan, Jaipur, 1987, p. 41 He was awarded D. Litt. by Beneras Hindu University. ===Ghanshyam Das Birla=== Ghanshyam Das Birla laid the foundation of his industrial empire by establishing GM Birla Company, trading in [[jute]], in 1911. The [[First World War]] began in 1914 greatly increasing the demand for jute sacks. During the war the Birla's worth is estimated to have risen from 2 million rupees to 8 million.{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=xcbBEHHI-90C&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q&f=false|title=India's Industrialists|first1=Margaret|last1=Herdeck|first2=Gita|last2=Piramal|date=9 July 1985|publisher=Lynne Rienner Publishers|accessdate=9 July 2017|via=Google Books}} In 1919, he became among the first group of Indian entrepreneurs to become owner of a Jute mill named [[Birla Corporation|Birla Jute]].{{cite web|url=http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/magazines/corporate-dossier/family-spirit-and-frugality-help-the-birlas-keep-pace-with-changing-times/articleshow/41702203.cms?intenttarget=no|title='Family' spirit and frugality help the Birlas keep pace with changing times|date=6 September 2014|publisher=|accessdate=9 July 2017|via=The Economic Times}} In the next few years he acquired several cotton mills. He later started several sugar mills. The publication [[Hindustan Times]] was co-founded by GD Birla in 1924 and fully acquired by him in 1933. [[Hindustan Motors]] was started in 1942. After India's independence in 1947 he started [[Grasim]] (Gwalior Rayon Silk Manufacturing, 1948) and [[Hindalco]] (Hindustan Aluminium Company 1958) among others. Baldeo Das, as well his sons were among the key supporters of the [[swaraj]] movement led by Mahatma Gandhi, in addition to being dedicated Hindu activists. They were active supporters of the [[Banaras Hindu University]] founded by Pt. [[Madan Mohan Malaviya]] and were also financial supporters of activities initiated by Mahatma Gandhi.Business Legends, Gita Piramal, Penguin UK, Dec 1, 2010 The landmark [[Laxminarayan Temple]] in Delhi was built by Jugal Kishore Birla and was inaugurated by Mahatma Gandhi and as asked by Mahatma, all Hindus, including [[harijan]]s were welcomed in this temple. In the few decades before India's independence, Indian merchants, including the Birlas, made successful attempts to enter and acquire industries in India which were once dominated by [[Scot]]s from Britain.{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1943/01/02/archives/british-investors-see-peril-in-india-managing-agents-fear-loss-of.html|title=British Investors See Peril in India – Managing Agents Fear Loss of Immense Profits on Half of Country's Industries – Natives Seek Business – Huge Sterling Credits Already Available to Buy Out the Foreign Companies|first=Herbert L.|last=Matthews|date=2 January 1943|page=5| work=New York Times|accessdate=9 July 2017}} This became a part of Mahatma Gandhi's [[Swadeshi]] movement. Birlas remained close to some of the leaders of India, like [[Sardar Patel]] after India's independence.Debajyoti Burman, Mystery of Birla House, Jugabani Hahitya Chakara, 3rd reprint 1951, P. 111 As leading industrialists, they were often accused by the leftists of exploiting their workers and aspiring to be among the richest in the world. Still when [[E. M. S. Namboodiripad]] became the chief minister of Kerala (1957–59), as a result of the first elected Marxist government anywhere, Birlas were invited to establish a pulp factory there.Phrases And Facts: About Kerala, Partha Choudhuri, Liberation, Vol. II, No. 3 (January 1969). In recent past, the Birlas, as well as several other Indian industrialists have expanded overseas. {{cite web|last=Piramal|first=Gita|url=http://www.india-seminar.com/1999/482/482%20piramal.htm|title= A crisis of leadership|date=October 1999|work=Family Business, a symposium on the role of the family in Indian business|publisher=|accessdate=9 July 2017}} ==Family Tree of Male MembersThis follows the common conventions.
