bottom}} ==Philanthropy== [[File:Gandhi at the Laxminarayan Temple.jpg|thumbnail|right| [[Gandhi]] inaugurating the [[Laxminarayan Temple]], Delhi, 1938, with the Birla family (Jugalkishor, Rameshwardas, Ghanshyamdas in black caps, Baldevdas in turban]] Birla philanthropy began in the 1880s, when the Birla family donated over 100,000 rupees for setting up goshalas (shelters for the protection of cows) in Kolkata. By early 1900, the Birla family began to support education, influenced by Pandit Madan Mohan Malaviya. They supported educational charities in Kolkata and in Mumbai teaming up with [[Jamnalal Bajaj]]. In 1918, the family established the first high school in Pilani which evolved into [[BITS Pilani]], which now has branches in Hyderabad, Goa and Dubai. They also opened a Sanskrit library in Benares and a library in Kolkata.{{cite web|url=http://www.livemint.com/Specials/XaccWERecP1ckwaJ4spx5O/Rajashree-Birla--Giving-is-in-fact-living.html|title=Rajashree Birla - Giving is in fact living|first=Rajashree|last=Birla|date=3 October 2014|publisher=|accessdate=9 July 2017}} It is well known for the financial support of Indian's freedom struggle and for building temples (see [[Birla Temple]]) in several major Indian cities. The institutions founded by the Birlas include: * [[Birla Planetarium (disambiguation)|Birla Planetarium]]s * [[Guru Hanuman]] Akhara * [[Aditya Birla Memorial Hospital]] * [[Birla Institute of Technology and Science, Pilani]] * [[Birla Institute of Management Technology]] (BIMTECH), Greater Noidahttp://bimtech.ac.in/about/the-legacy-the-birla-group/ * [[Birla Global University]] Bhubaneswar, Odisha{{cite web|url=https://www.bgu.ac.in/|title=Birla Global University - Top University in BBSR, Odisha|website=www.bgu.ac.in|accessdate=9 July 2017}} * [[Birla Institute of Technology, Mesra]] * [[Birla Vishwakarma Mahavidyalaya]] * Birla Education Trust, Pilani * [[M. P. Birla Foundation Higher Secondary School]] * [[Technological Institute of Textile & Sciences]], Bhiwani * [[M. P. Birla Institute of Fundamental Research]] * [[Basant Kumar Birla#Philanthropy|BK Birla Group institutions]], [[Aditya Birla Group#Philanthropy|Aditya Birla Group Institutions]] * [[K. K. Birla Foundation]], established in 1991 by Krishna Kumar Birla, gives the annual awards like [[Saraswati Samman]], [[Vyas Samman]] and [[G.D. Birla Award for Scientific Research]].{{cite web | title = Govind Mishra gets Saraswati Samman 2013 for novel 'Dhool Paudhon Par' |work= Daily News & Analysis| url = http://www.dnaindia.com/india/report-govind-mishra-gets-saraswati-samman-2013-for-novel-dhool-paudhon-par-2020773 |date=22 September 2014 | accessdate = 2014-09-23 }} [[File:'Birla Brothers' Plaque at 'Dhosi Hill'.jpg|thumbnail|right| Birla Brothers' of Pilani, who established 'BITS, Pilani' also got constructed a Dam in the year 1944 or Vikrami Samvat 2000 on 'Dhosi Hill' to store rainy water for bathing of 'Pilgrims']] ==Birla values== In a letter, Ghanshaym Das offered this advice to Aditya (his grandson) when he was studying at MIT: :“eat only vegetarian food, never drink alcohol or smoke, keep early hours, marry young, switch-off lights when leaving the room, cultivate regular habits, go for a walk everyday, keep in touch with the family, and above all, don’t be extravagant.” India's Industrialists, Volume 1, Margaret Herdeck, Gita Piramal, Lynne Rienner Publishers, 1985 p. 97 GD Birla instructed his son Basant Kumar to 'never utilize wealth only for fun and frolic,' to 'spend the bare minimum on yourself,' and to deride 'worldly pleasures.' This advice symbolised the ethic of the rising Marwari community, with restraint and austerity its defining attributes.{{cite web|url=http://gurcharandas.org/node/634|title=Marwari ethic and the spirit of Capitalism - Gurcharan Das|website=gurcharandas.org|accessdate=9 July 2017}} ==Birla Family ties== Although the Birlas are perceived as a single entity, the different branches of the family are now financially independent.{{cite web|url=http://www.thehindubusinessline.com/2004/08/26/stories/2004082602130600.htm|title=The Hindu Business Line : `Mahatma was witness to Birla clan partition'|first=|last=cakml|website=www.thehindubusinessline.com|accessdate=9 July 2017}}{{cite web|url=http://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/after-months-of-tension-birlas-part-ways-amicably/1/337575.html|title=After months of tension, Birlas part ways amicably|publisher=|accessdate=9 July 2017}} However they have continued to maintain family relationships that go back to the times when "Birla Brothers" were an actual entity and Raja Baldevdas was still alive. Both of GD Birla's wives died early because of tuberculosis (He remarried after the death of his first wife), a common affliction at that time. The families of his brothers [[Ghanshyam Das Birla#Family history|Brij Mohan and Rameshwar Das Birla helped in raising his children]]. When Yash Birla's parents died in a plane crash, Priyamvada Birla, ("Badi Ma") helped take care of him.{{cite web|url=http://www.thehindu.com/features/magazine/yash-gets-candid/article5875980.ece|title=Yash gets candid|publisher=|accessdate=9 July 2017}} It is reported that Kumar Mangalam Birla had dipped into his own resources to help his beleaguered relative Yash with his financial issues with creditors, in order to preserve the family name.{{cite web|url=http://www.mid-day.com/articles/family-values/238587|title=Family Values|publisher=|accessdate=9 July 2017}} =="Tata-Birla" word pair== For many decades the extreme wealth in India was associated with the Tatas and Birlas. The words Tata-Birla were often used together.[http://www.mathrubhumi.com/english/news/columns/below-the-belt/capitalists-of-the-world-unite-4323.html Capitalists of the world, unite! Mathrubhumi, October 9, 2008] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402100733/http://www.mathrubhumi.com/english/news/columns/below-the-belt/capitalists-of-the-world-unite-4323.html |date=April 2, 2015 }} They were distantly followed by [[Dalmia Group|Dalmia]]s (Dalmia-Sahu Jain group) for some time,{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Pi5bAAAAMAAJ&q=Tata,+Birla,+Dalmia-Jain,+Hirachand,+B.+Mukherjee+and+M.+Chettiar&dq=Tata,+Birla,+Dalmia-Jain,+Hirachand,+B.+Mukherjee+and+M.+Chettiar&hl=en&sa=X&ei=V30gVZiIBYitogT6goCAAg&ved=0CB0Q6AEwAA|title=World Marxist Review|date=9 July 1970|publisher=Progress Books.|accessdate=9 July 2017|via=Google Books}} however Tatas and Birlas have been able to sustain themselves as among the most prominent industrialists in India (for 1939-1997 data see{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=X6knIE-47BAC&pg=PA290&lpg=PA290&dq=tata+birla+dalmia&source=bl&ots=b3ZlTXgn77&sig=tLsx13Ep23ORRTWJ_IrZ4ZEQzNE&hl=en&sa=X&ei=hasYVcaCApWyoQTi24DoDg&ved=0CE0Q6AEwBg#v=onepage&q=tata+birla+dalmia&f=false|title=A History of Corporate Governance around the World: Family Business Groups to Professional Managers|first=Randall K.|last=Morck|date=1 November 2007|publisher=University of Chicago Press|accessdate=9 July 2017|via=Google Books}}) while others have declined. [http://swaminomics.org/the-curse-of-too-many-sons/ The Curse of too-many Sons, Swaminathan S. Anklesaria Aiyar, Times of India, Nov 9, 1997]{{cite web|url=http://www.businessandeconomy.org/14122006/storyd.asp?sid=641&pageno=25|title=The Rise, Fall & Rise Of Indian Business Families|first=Website Developed by Ranjit Singh, Planman Media Pvt. Ltd., Delhi, India|last=9811747788|website=www.businessandeconomy.org|accessdate=9 July 2017}} A plan for development of India was developed by a group of industrialists in 1944, which was termed the Tata-Birla plan or the Bombay plan,{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=iLvyf6jQYqYC&pg=PA184&dq=Tata+Birla&hl=en&sa=X&ei=8a8YVYHjLtPaoASit4DgBA&ved=0CEgQ6AEwCA#v=onepage&q=Tata+Birla&f=false|title=Tata Consultancy Services Story- and Beyond|first=Subramaniam|last=Ramadorai|date=9 July 2017|publisher=Penguin Books India|accessdate=9 July 2017|via=Google Books}} which is said to have served as a blueprint for India's [[Five-Year Plans of India#First Plan .281951-1956.29|first five-year plan]]. Two South India comedy movies [[Tata Birla Madhyalo Laila]] and [[Tata Birla]] use the word pair. It also occurs in some songs.{{cite web|url=http://ibnlive.in.com/news/tata-birla-song-is-not-meant-to-disrespect-anyone-prakash-jha/297699-8-66.html|title=News18.com: CNN News18 Latest News, Breaking News India, Current News Headlines|website=News18|accessdate=9 July 2017}} ==References== {{reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Birla Family}} [[Category:Family trees]] [[Category:Indian families]] [[Category:Hindu families]] [[Category:Business families of India]] [[Category:Birla family]]

{{small|([[Master of Science]] in [[Petroleum Geoscience]])}} | occupation = [[Geologist]] and [[Civil servant]] | years_active = 2007 — present | known_for = Technical competence | home_town = [[Soroti]]? | title = [[Geologist]] in the Petroleum Exploration and Production Department of the [[Ministry of Energy and Mineral Development (Uganda)|Uganda Ministry of Energy and Mineral Development]] | spouse = | networth = | }} '''Catherine Amusugut''' is a [[Uganda]]n geologist and [[civil servant]], who serves as a [[Geologist]] at the Petroleum Exploration and Production Department (PEPD), in the [[Ministry of Energy and Mineral Development (Uganda)|Uganda Ministry of Energy and Mineral Development]], since January 2007.{{cite web|last=Flavia Nalubega |location=Kampala | url=http://www.oilinuganda.org/features/local-content/women-climb-the-technical-ladder.html |title=Women and Oil: Women climb the technical ladder | date=17 May 2013 |accessdate=8 November 2017 |publisher=Oilinuganda.org (OINUG) | first=and Beatrice Ongode}} ==Background and education== She was educated at [[Makerere University]], Uganda's largest and oldest public university, where she graduated with a [[Bachelor of Science]] in [[Geology]] and [[Chemistry]]. Later, in 2010, she obtained a [[Master of Science]] in [[Petroleum Geoscience]], from the [[University of Aberdeen]], in [[Scotland]]. ==Career== Amusugut joined the PEPD in January 2007, beginning as Geologist-trainee, while she was still an undergraduate at Makerere University. Following her graduation with a BSc degree in geology, she was hired full-time as a geologist. Her responsibilities include reviewing the work plans submitted by the oil companies to make sure the plans are efficient and geologically, environmentally and commercially "viable". If all the criteria are met, permission to proceed with drilling is granted. In this capacity, she interacts with [[corporate executive]]s of international oil companies, on the best plan of action.{{cite web| url=https://www.linkedin.com/in/cathy-amusugut-833a6440/ | title=Cathy Amusugut, Geologist at Petroleum Exploration and Production Department, Uganda Ministry of Energy and Minerals | date=8 November 2017 |accessdate=8 November 2017 |publisher=[[Linkedin.com]] | author=Cathy Amusugut}} ==Scientific writings== Ms. Amusugut has written several scientific papers in her area of expertise, which have been presented at international {{Infobox person | name = Christoph Sutter | image = | image_size = | caption = | birth_date = 20 March 1973<ref name="up.ethz.ch">{{Cite web|url=http://www.up.ethz.ch/people/former/csutter/CV_ChristophSutter.pdf|title=CV from Swiss Federal Institute of Technologies, former members}}</ref> | birth_place = [[Basel]], [[Switzerland]]<ref name="up.ethz.ch"/> | death_date = | death_place = | occupation = Carbon professional | spouse = | parents = | children = 1 son<ref name="karriere-journal.monster.de">{{cite web|url=https://www.monster.de/karriereberatung/artikel/teilzeit-arbeiten-mit-strategie|title=Teilzeit arbeiten mit Strategie|website=Monster Career Advice}}</ref> }} '''Christoph Sutter''' (born 20 March 1973)<ref name="up.ethz.ch"/> is a [[Switzerland|Swiss]] carbon expert and [[entrepreneur]]. Christoph attended the [[ETH Zurich|Swiss Federal Institute of Technology]] where he studied for an MSc in Environmental Science (1993–1999) and a Master of Didactics on Environmental Science. He also concluded his PhD on the Topic "Sustainability Assessment of CDM Projects under the Kyoto Protocol" there. His thesis was awarded the ETH medal for the best PhD thesis in 2003.<ref name="up.ethz.ch"/> He completed his education with a McKinsey mini MBA in Toronto in Summer 2005.
After working for the consultancy Ernst Basler & Partner in Zurich during his studies he was part of setting up the [[myclimate]] foundation based on his PhD results. Myclimate is an offset provider for the voluntary offsetting market, focused on [[CDM Gold Standard]] Certificates.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nachhaltigkeit.org/200911113422/mensch-gesellschaft/interviews/klimamarkt-braucht-klare-signale |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-01-11 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110214170120/http://www.nachhaltigkeit.org/200911113422/mensch-gesellschaft/interviews/klimamarkt-braucht-klare-signale |archivedate=2011-02-14 |df= }}</ref> During this activity, Christoph was called to work for the [[UNFCCC]] Methodology Panel in 2005 where he worked for 3 years.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nzz.ch/vermittler_zwischen_umwelt_und_wirtschaft-1.812553|title=Vermittler zwischen Umwelt und Wirtschaft - NZZ|date=21 August 2008|publisher=|via=NZZ}}</ref> Unsatisfied with the exclusive focus on voluntary offsetting, he later founded the company [http://www.southpolecarbon.com] [[South Pole Carbon]] with his former colleagues Thomas Camerata and [[Renat Heuberger]].
He was Co-CEO of South Pole Carbon Asset Management Ltd from 2006 until 2012, but continue to act as non-executive chairman and shareholder.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121203030354/http://www.southpolecarbon.com:80/media/archive_news|title=Archive – News - South Pole Carbon|date=3 December 2012|publisher=}}</ref> On 1 June 2012 he joined Swiss power generator Axpo as Head of Asset Development.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://web.archive.org/web/1999/issuu.com/carbon-tradingmagazine/docs/carbon_trading_june_2012#d604c21a-a326-11e1-bc49-12313b063a65|title=ISSUU - Page not found|publisher=}}</ref>
He was awarded as one of the WEF [[Young Global Leaders]] in 2009.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wirtschaft.ch/WEF+nominiert+Christoph+Sutter+als+Young+Global+Leader/374795/detail.htm|title=WEF nominiert Christoph Sutter als Young Global Leader|first=VADIAN.NET|last=AG|publisher=}}</ref>
Additionally, Christoph is actively engaged in the work-life balance community, as he reduced his workload to 80%, taking off on Fridays, after the birth of his son.<ref name="karriere-journal.monster.de"/>

but don't try to convert anyone|work=BBC|first=Matthew|last=Teller|date=12 July 2015|accessdate=12 July 2015|quote=Ten-thousand or more live in the UAE, and young, bearded priest Father Markos, 12 years in Dubai, told me his flock are "more than happy - they enjoy their life, they are free."}} |region8 = {{flagcountry|Jordan}} |pop8 = 8,000+ (2005) |ref8 = {{lower|{{cite web|url=http://www.jordanembassyus.org/06032005001.htm |title=King commends Coptic Church's role in promoting coexistence |publisher=Jordanembassyus.org |date=June 3, 2005 |accessdate=November 18, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110926234617/http://www.jordanembassyus.org/06032005001.htm |archivedate=September 26, 2011 |df= }}}} |region9 = {{flagcountry|Kenya}} |pop9 = 8,000+ |ref9 = {{lower|[http://www.copticafrica.org/bookcomehelp3.htm Come Across And Help Us Book 2] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081008090221/http://www.copticafrica.org/bookcomehelp3.htm |date=October 8, 2008 }}[http://www.copticmission.org/copticmission CopticMission] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110131014720/http://www.copticmission.org/copticmission |date=January 31, 2011 }}}} |region10 = {{flagcountry|Lebanon}} |pop10 = 3,000 – 4,000 (2012) |ref10 = {{lower|{{cite news|url=https://www.state.gov/j/drl/rls/irf/2012/nea/208400.htm |title=Lebanon: Bureau of Democracy, Human Rights, and Labor - 2012 Report on International Religious Freedom |agency=U.S. Department of State |date=20 May 2013 |accessdate=6 December 2015}}}} |languages = Diaspora: [[English language|English]], [[French language|French]] and others.
Only in Egypt, Sudan, Libya spoken: [[Arabic language|Arabic]].
Liturgical: [[Coptic language]]. |religions = Predominantly: [[Coptic Orthodox Church of Alexandria|Coptic Orthodoxy]].
Minorities: [[Coptic Catholic Church|Coptic Catholicism]] and various [[Protestantism in Egypt|Protestant]] denominations.}} The '''Coptic diaspora''' consists of [[Copts]] who live outside of their primary area of residence within parts of present-day [[Egypt]], [[Libya]] and [[Sudan]]. The number of Copts outside [[Egypt]] has sharply increased since the 1960s. The largest Coptic diaspora populations are [[Coptic Americans|in the United States]], [[Coptic Canadians|in Canada]] and [[Coptic Australians|in Australia]], but Copts have a presence in many other countries. ==Population== [[File:StMarkCopticOrthodoxChurchBellaireTX0.JPG|thumb|180px|St. Mark Coptic Orthodox Church in [[Bellaire, Texas]], in the United States.]] {{Copts}} [[Copts in Egypt]] make up about 5-20% of the population.{{refn|Independent estimates of the size of the Egyptian Coptic population vary. The ''Oxford Handbook of Global Religions'' reports: "There are conflicting estimates for the size of Egypt's Coptic population. As is often the case with minorities, official counts tend to underestimate their size, while the minority group inflates its own numbers."Juan E. Campo & John Iskander, "The Coptic Community" in ''The Oxford Handbook of Global Religions'' (ed. Mark Juergensmeyer: Oxford University Press, 2006), p. 317. The BBC reported in 2004 that Copts make up between 5% and 10% of the Egyptian population.{{cite news |title=Egyptian Coptic protesters freed |first= |last= |newspaper=BBC |date=22 December 2004 |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/4117831.stm |accessdate=}} The ''[[CIA World Factbook]]'' reported a 2012 estimate that the Christian community in Egypt (including both Copts and non-Copts) is about 10%.{{cite web |url=https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/eg.html |title=Egypt |author= |date= |work=The World Factbook |publisher=[[CIA]] |accessdate=27 August 2010}} A 2005 report by the [[Washington Institute for Near East Policy]] reported that "Christians make up 10-20 percent of Egypt's population of seventy-seven million, though precise estimates of the number of Copts vary widely."{{cite web |url=http://www.washingtoninstitute.org/templateC05.php?CID=2386 |title=The Copts and Their Political Implications in Egypt |author=Khairi Abaza and Mark Nakhla |date=25 October 2005 |work= |publisher=Washington Institute for Near East Policy}}}} [[Copts in Sudan]] make up about half a million or 1% of Sudanese population.Minority Rights Group International, World Directory of Minorities and Indigenous Peoples – Sudan : Copts, 2008, available at: http://www.unhcr.org/refworld/docid/49749ca6c.html [accessed 21 December 2010] There are about 60,000 [[Copts in Libya]], making up the majority of [[Christianity in Libya|that country's Christian community]].Jason Morgan et al., ''Culture and Customs of Libya'' (ABC-CLIO, 2012), p. 40. There are about 60,000 [[Copts in Libya]], 1% of Libyan population, [http://i-cias.com/e.o/coptic_c.htm Looklex Encyclopedia: 1% of Libya's population (6 million), or 60,000 people in Libya, adhere to the Coptic Orthodox faith] making up the majority of [[Christianity in Libya|that country's Christian community]].Jason Morgan et al., ''Culture and Customs of Libya'' (ABC-CLIO, 2012), p. 40. Outside of the traditional Coptic areas in Egypt, Sudan and Libya, the largest Coptic diaspora populations are [[Coptic Americans|in the United States]], [[Coptic Canadians|in Canada]] and [[Coptic Australians|in Australia]]."Diaspora, Copts in the" at ''The A to Z of the Coptic Church'' (ed. Gawdat Gabra: [[Scarecrow Press]], 2009), pp. 91-92. According to one scholar: "Estimations of the actual number of Egyptian Copts (and their descendants leaving abroad vary enormously, with those circulated by Coptic expatriate activists. The biggest Coptic community abroad, that of the United States, included up to 1,000,000 persons in the late 2010s according to Coptic advocacy groups, but only 300,000 according to the [[Coptic Orthodox Church in the United States]] itself, and even less—roughly between 100,000 and 200,000--according to the scarce statistical evidence supplied by the Egyptian and U.S. governments." Smaller communities of Copts exist [[Copts in Australia|in Australia]] (estimated 32,000 in 2006) and in Canada (estimates vary: one 2001 estimate placed the population at 10,000 while a 1995 estimate placed the population at 50,000). Smaller communities (under 10,000 people) exist in Britain, France, Germany, Austria, Switzerland, and Italy. In 2009 one scholar placed the total Coptic population of [[North America]] at more than 500,000.Seteney Shami, "'Aqualliyya/Minority in Modern Egyptian Discourse" in ''Words in Motion: Toward a Global Lexicon'' (eds. Carol Gluck & Anna Lowenhaupt Tsing: Duke University Press, 2009), p. 168. In 1999, it was reported that there were "over eighty Coptic churches, two theological colleges, and a monastery in the United States in Canada; twenty-five churches, a theological college, three schools, and two monasteries in Australia, and thirty churches and two monasteries in Europe."Otto Friedrich August Meinardus, ''Two Thousand Years of Coptic Christianity'' ([[American University in Cairo Press]]: 1999), p. 81. There is also a Coptic presence in [[Lebanon]] and [[Jordan]], and well as the [[Arab states of the Persian Gulf]], such as the [[United Arab Emirates]].Otto Friedrich August Meinardus, ''Two Thousand Years of Coptic Christianity'' ([[American University in Cairo Press]]: 1999), p. 129. There is also a Coptic presence (due to recent missionary work) in the [[sub-Saharan Africa]]n countries of Zambia, Kenya, Zaire, Zimbabwe, Namibia, and South Africa.Otto Friedrich August Meinardus, ''Two Thousand Years of Coptic Christianity'' ([[American University in Cairo Press]]: 1999), p. 123. ==Causes and history of the Coptic diaspora== The Coptic diaspora began primarily in the 1950s as result of [[discrimination]], [[persecution of Copts]] and low income in Egypt.Afe Adogame, ''The African Christian Diaspora: New Currents and Emerging Trends in World Christianity'' ([[A & C Black]], 2013), p. 72.Ken Parry, ''The Blackwell Companion to Eastern Christianity'' (John Wiley & Sons, 2010), p. 107. After [[Gamal Abdel Nasser]] rose to power, economic and social conditions deteriorated and many wealthier Egyptians, especially Copts, emigrated to Europe and the United States. Emigration increased following the [[1967 Arab-Israeli war]], and the emigration of poorer and less-educated Copts increased after 1972, when the [[World Council of Churches]] and other religious groups began assisting Copt immigration. Emigration of Egyptian Copts increased under [[Anwar al-Sadat]] (with many taking advantage of Sadat's "[[Infitah|open door]]" policy to leave the country) and under [[Hosni Mubarak]]. Many Copts are university graduates in the professions, such as medicine and engineering. ==See also== *[[Coptic flag]] *[[List of Copts]] *[[Coptic Orthodox Church in Asia]] *[[Coptic Orthodox Church in Malaysia]] *[[Coptic Orthodox Church in Europe]] *[[French Coptic Orthodox Church]] *[[Coptic Orthodox Church in Britain and Ireland]] *[[Coptic Orthodox Church in North America]] *[[Coptic Orthodox Church in Canada]] *[[Coptic Orthodox Church in Mexico]] *[[List of Coptic Orthodox Churches in Canada]] *[[Coptic Orthodox Church in South America]] *[[List of active separatist movements in Africa#Egypt]] ==References== ==External links== {{Coptic diaspora}} [[Category:Coptic diaspora| ]] [[Category:Coptic people]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2016}} {{Infobox person | name = Daniel Lind Lagerlöf | image = | imagesize = | alt = | caption = | birthname = Daniel Magnus Gösta Lind | birth_date = {{birth date|1969|2|6|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[Stockholm]], Sweden | disappeared_date = {{Disappeared date and age|2011|10|6|1969|2|6|df=yes}} | disappeared_place = near [[Tanumshede]], Sweden | disappeared_status = {{Missing for|2011|10|6}}, Presumed dead | othername = | nationality = [[Swedes|Swedish]] | occupation = Film director, screenwriter, producer | yearsactive = 1990–2011 | spouse = Malin Lagerlöf | children = 3 | website = }} '''Daniel Lind Lagerlöf''' (born 6 February 1969; missing since 6 October 2011) is a [[presumed dead]] [[Swedes|Swedish]] [[film director|director]], [[screenwriter]] and [[film producer|producer]]
== Career == Lagerlöf began his work in television as an assistant, and directed his first film, ''Föreställningen'' (''The Performance'') in 1990. In 1997 he began working on ''Skärgårdsdoktorn'', a highly successful drama series in Sweden and Norway. After it ended in 2000, Lagerlöf worked on several ''Beck''-films, before returning to television. His last completed project was the three-part mini-series ''Bibliotekstjuven'' (the Library Thief), written by his wife Malin Lagerlöf.
== Personal life == Lagerlöf met his wife, Malin Lagerlöf, in the early 1990s, and they married soon after. They had three children together. A screenwriter, Malin Lagerlöf often wrote projects for her husband to direct, including his final series, ''Bibliotekstjuven''.
== Disappearance == On 6 October 2011, Lagerlöf disappeared during preparations for the filming of [[Camilla Läckberg]]'s ''[[Fjällbackamorden]] - Strandriddaren'' while scouting a planned filming location in the Tjurpannan nature reserve, leaving a wife and three children.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.expressen.se/gt/malins-man-forsvann-finns-mycket-hopp/|title=Malins man försvann: "Finns mycket hopp"|access-date=2018-08-28|language=sv-SE}}</ref>
It is believed Lagerlöf was caught on slippery rocks by large waves sweeping the area and pulled out to sea near the steep cliffs outside [[Tanumshede]] in [[Bohuslän]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.expressen.se/gt/malins-man-forsvann-finns-mycket-hopp/|title=Malins man försvann: "Finns mycket hopp"|access-date=2018-08-28|language=sv-SE}}</ref> There were no witnesses to what actually happened. {{as of|2016}} no remains have been found, and Lagerlöf is presumed deceased.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.aftonbladet.se/nyheter/article13750407.ab |title=Försvann vid havet: Regissören Daniel Lind Lagerlöf försvunnen |trans-title=Vanished at Sea: Director Daniel Lind Lagerlöf missing |date=9 October 2011 |work=[[Aftonbladet]] |accessdate=28 June 2014 |language=sv}}</ref><ref name="hollywoodreporter">{{cite web |first=Scott |last=Roxborough |url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/swedish-director-david-lind-lagerlof-246078 |title=Swedish Director David Lind Lagerlof Still Missing, Presumed Dead |accessdate=21 June 2012 |newspaper=[[The Hollywood Reporter]] |date=10 October 2011}}</ref><ref name="screendaily">{{cite web|first=Gunnar |last=Rehlin |url=http://www.screendaily.com/news/europe/swedish-director-lagerlof-presumed-dead-after-location-scouting-accident/5033090.article |title=Swedish director Lagerlof presumed dead after location scouting accident |accessdate=21 June 2012 |work=[[Screen Daily]] |date=9 October 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131101095426/http://www.screendaily.com/news/europe/swedish-director-lagerlof-presumed-dead-after-location-scouting-accident/5033090.article |archivedate=1 November 2013 |df= }}</ref>
==Selected filmography== * 1999 – ''[[Vägen ut|Breaking out]]'' (''Vägen ut'') * 2001 – ''[[Making Babies]]'' (''Hans och hennes'') * 2002 – ''[[Beck – Annonsmannen]]'' * 2002 – ''[[Beck – Pojken i glaskulan]]'' * 2003 – ''[[Miffo]]'' * 2005 - ''Buss till Italien'' * 2005 - ''Medicinmannen'' * 2006 - ''Svalan, katten, rosen, döden'' * 2007 - ''The Pyramid'' * 2009 - ''The Man Under the Stairs'' (TV-series) * 2009 - ''[[Johan Falk|Johan Falk: Operation Nightingale]]''

{{use dmy dates|date=November 2012}} {{Infobox President | name = Dany Chamoun | native_name = داني شمعون | native_name_lang = ar | image =Dany Chamoun - 1988.jpg | caption =Dany Chamoun in 1988 | office1 = [[National Liberal Party (Lebanon)|President of the National Liberal Party]] | term_start1 = 1985 | term_end1 = 1990 | predecessor1 = [[Camille Chamoun]] | successor1 = [[Dory Chamoun]] | birth_date = {{Birth date |1934|08|26|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Deir el Qamar]], [[Lebanon]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|1990|10|21|1934|08|26|df=y}} | death_place = [[Beirut]], Lebanon | religion = [[Maronite Church]] | party = [[National Liberal Party (Lebanon)|National Liberal Party]] }} '''Dany Chamoun''' ({{lang-ar|داني شمعون}}) (26 August 1934 – 21 October 1990) was a prominent [[Lebanon|Lebanese]] politician. A [[Maronite Christianity in Lebanon|Maronite]] Christian, the younger son of former [[List of Presidents of Lebanon|President]] [[Camille Chamoun]] and brother of [[Dory Chamoun]], Chamoun was also a politician in his own right, and was known for his opposition to the occupation of Lebanese territory by foreign forces, whether [[Military of Syria|Syrian]] or [[Military of Israel|Israeli]].
==Life and career== ===Early life and education=== Chamoun was born in [[Deir el-Qamar]] on 26 August 1934.<ref name=wofl>{{cite web|title=Dany Chamoun |url=http://wars.meskawi.nl/people.html#6|publisher=Wars of Lebanon|accessdate=27 January 2013}}</ref> He was the younger son of the former President [[Camille Chamoun]]. He studied civil engineering in [[the United Kingdom]].<ref name=tatro>{{cite news|last=Tatro|first=Earleen F.|title=Lebanon: Dynasties dominate life...|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=8ohGAAAAIBAJ&sjid=l_IMAAAAIBAJ&pg=1402,1319470&dq=dany+chamoun&hl=en|accessdate=31 December 2012|newspaper=The Lewiston Journal|date=10 February 1983|agency=AP|location=Beirut}}</ref>
===Political career=== Chamoun reported that he had not had any interest in politics before the Lebanon civil war.<ref name=tatro/> He became the [[National Liberal Party (Lebanon)|National Liberal Party]] Secretary of Defense in January 1976, after the death of its predecessor Naim Berdkan. As Supreme Commander of the NLP's military wing, the [[Tigers Militia (Lebanon)|Tigers]], he also played a major role in the early years of the [[Lebanese Civil War]].<ref name="Jaber">{{cite news|last1=Jaber|first1=Ali|title=Leader of a Major Christian Clan in Beirut Is Assassinated with His Family|work=The New York Times|page=3|date=22 October 1990|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/22/world/leader-of-a-major-christian-clan-in-beirut-is-assassinated-with-his-family.html}}</ref>
In 1976, the NLP Tigers under Dany's command along with the [[Kataeb|Phalangist]] [[Kataeb Regulatory Forces]], [[Al-Tanzim]], and [[Guardians of the Cedars]] formed a joined militia command under the name [[Lebanese Forces]].
By 1980, the [[Kataeb|Phalangist]]-dominated [[Lebanese Forces]] were under the command of [[Bachir Gemayel]]. Rivalry began to arise between Bashir and Dany. Dany's Tigers were eliminated as a military force in a [[Safra massacre|massacre]] perpetrated on 7 July 1980 by the rival Phalangists. Chamoun's life was spared and he fled to the [[Sunni Islam in Lebanon|Sunni Muslim]]-dominated West [[Beirut]]. He then went into self-imposed exile.<ref name=mg>{{cite news|title=Lebanon's Christians|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=Pn8xAAAAIBAJ&sjid=C6UFAAAAIBAJ&pg=1470,378444&dq=ehden+massacre&hl=en|accessdate=6 November 2012|newspaper=The Montreal Gazette|date=22 September 1982}}</ref>
Chamoun was a supporter of the nationalist Christian cause at heart, however, and he soon returned to the cause to which he, like his father, had dedicated his life. He served as General Secretary of the National Liberal Party from 1983 to 1985, when he replaced his father as the party leader.<ref name=gherald>{{cite news|title=Syria has Waite, says Christian leader|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=RxA1AAAAIBAJ&sjid=sKULAAAAIBAJ&pg=3423,524318&dq=dany+chamoun&hl=en|accessdate=31 December 2012|newspaper=The Glasgow Herald|date=3 April 1987}}</ref> In 1988, he became President of the revived [[Lebanese Front]]—a coalition of nationalist and mainly Christian parties and politicians that his father had helped to found. The same year, he announced his candidacy for the Presidency of Lebanon to succeed [[Amine Gemayel]] (Bashir's brother), but [[Syria]] (which by this time occupied some 70 percent of Lebanese territory) vetoed his candidacy.
Gemayel's term expired on 23 September 1988 without the election of a successor. Chamoun declared his strong support for [[Michel Aoun]], who had been appointed by the outgoing president to lead an interim administration and went on to lead one of two rival governments that contended for power over the next two years. He strongly opposed the [[Taif Agreement]], which not only gave a greater share of power to the Muslim community than they had enjoyed previously, but more seriously, in Chamoun's opinion, formalized what he saw as the master-servant relationship between Syria and Lebanon, and refused to recognize the new government of the President [[Elias Hrawi]], who was elected under the Taif Agreement.
===Assassination=== On 21 October 1990, Chamoun, along with his German-born second wife Ingrid (forty-five), and his two sons, Tarek (seven) and Julian (five), were murdered.<ref name="LA Times">[http://articles.latimes.com/1995-06-25/news/mn-17158_1_civil-war-crimes "Lebanese Ex-Warlord Sentenced in Rival's Slaying : Mideast: Christian is the first militia chief convicted of civil war crimes. Many received amnesty. Eleven associates are also sentenced."], ''Los Angeles Times'', 25 June 1995. Retrieved on 22 October 2016.</ref> On 24 June 1995, the Lebanese Tribunal found [[Samir Geagea]] guilty of the assassination of Dany Chamoun and his family.<ref name="LA Times"/> Overwhelming evidence derived from investigations led to Geagea receiving a life sentence.<ref name="LA Times"/> The heavy sentence allegedly having been issued due to Syrian occupation influence on the tribunal, Geagea was released after the Syrian departure.<ref>Fisk, Robert. [https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/warlord-gets-life-but-plans-his-vacation-1588238.html "Warlord gets life, but plan his vacation"], ''[https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/warlord-gets-life-but-plans-his-vacation-1588238.html Independent]'',Robert Fisk, 25 June 1995.</ref><ref>Kennan, Rodeina. [http://community.seattletimes.nwsource.com/archive/?date=19950625&slug=2128197 "Lebanon Militia Leader's Sentence For Murders Fans Religious Tension "], ''[http://community.seattletimes.nwsource.com/archive/?date=19950625&slug=2128197]'', 25 June 1995.</ref>

{{multiple issues| {{more footnotes|date=May 2008}} {{BLP sources|date=May 2013}} }} {{Infobox murderer | name = Denis Lortie | image = | image_size = | caption = | occupation = Military Supply Technician | birth_name = Joseph Laurent Paul Denis Lortie | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1959|3|10}}https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=S_YioojS82I&list=WL&index=1 | birth_place = [[Ontario]] | death_date = | death_place = | cause = | conviction = [[Murder (Canadian law)|Second-degree murder]] in 1987 | conviction_penalty = [[Life imprisonment]] with no [[parole]] for ten years. | conviction_status = [[Parole Board of Canada|Full parole]] in 1996 | date = May 8, 1984 | targets = Premier [[René Lévesque]], and other members of the governing [[Parti Québécois]]. | locations = [[National Assembly of Quebec]], [[Quebec City]], Canada | fatalities = 3 | injuries = 13 | weapons = * Two [[Sterling submachine gun|C-1 Submachine gun]]s ([[9mm NATO]]) * [[Browning Hi-Power|Inglis pistol]] ([[9mm]]) * Knife | motive = Anger over the [[Parti Québécois]]'s advocating of a [[Francophone]] identity for [[Quebec]], as well as alleged [[mental illness]]. }} '''Denis Lortie''' (born March 10, 1959) is a former [[Canadian Forces]] [[corporal]]. In 1984, he stormed into the [[Parliament Building (Quebec)|National Assembly of Quebec building]] and opened fire with several firearms, killing three [[Quebec]] [[public servant|government employees]] and wounding 13 others. The National Assembly's [[Sergeant-at-Arms]], [[René Jalbert]], volunteered himself to serve as a hostage, and conversed with Lortie for several hours before convincing him to surrender to authorities. After a 1985 conviction of first-degree murder was overturned by the [[Quebec Court of Appeal]], Lortie pleaded guilty to reduced charges of second-degree murder in 1987, for which he was convicted to [[life imprisonment]] with no [[Parole#Canada|parole]] for ten years. Lortie was granted [[day parole]] in 1995, then full parole in 1996, and has since kept a low profile.{{citation needed|date=December 2016}} ==Life== {{Infobox military person | allegiance = {{flagicon|Canada}} [[Canada]] | branch = [[Canadian Forces]]
([[Logistics Branch]]) | serviceyears = ''?'' - 1984 | rank = [[Corporal]] | unit = [[Royal 22e Régiment|Royal 22e Régiment]] | spouse = *Lisa Levesque (divorced) *Unknown woman (married after release) | relations = 2 Children | laterwork = Convenience store clerk (after release) }} Joseph Laurent Paul Denis Lortie was born in Quebec, the youngest son of eight children, all of whom were physically and sexually abused by his father.{{Cite web|url=http://www.lacan.com/symptom15/?p=4|title=The Père-version of the Political in the Case of Denis LortieWolfram Bergande – the SINTHOME 15|website=www.lacan.com|access-date=2016-11-30}} Lortie's father reportedly fathered a child with one of his daughters. One of them finally went to the police and in 1969, Lortie's father was sentenced to three years in prison. Upon his release he did not return to his family. Lortie joined the army and was stationed in [[Halifax, Nova Scotia|Halifax]], where he met and married Lisa Levesque in 1980.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=WFPAvt5iDnoC&lpg=PA321&ots=LqyTpG2a_Z&dq=lortie%20access%20to%20weapons&pg=PA264#v=onepage&q=Lortie&f=false|title=Rampage: Canadian Mass Murder and Spree Killing|last=Mellor|first=Lee|date=2013-03-09|publisher=Dundurn|isbn=9781459707221|language=en}} The couple had a son in 1982 and a daughter in 1983. At the time of the shooting, Lortie was stationed in [[CFS Carp]], near [[Ottawa]], was ranked a corporal, and worked as a [[supply technician]] in the [[Canadian Forces]] [[Logistics Branch]]. Lortie was bilingual, but his English was relatively poor, and even when speaking French (his native language), he encountered pronunciation difficulties, resulting in irregular and halting speech. Lortie blamed his social and professional failures on his inability to speak English flawlessly, and was keenly aware that his poor English reinforced negative stereotypes of [[Geographical distribution of French speakers|Francophones]] and [[Québécois people|Québécois]]. After the birth of his daughter, Lortie worried that he would become abusive in the manner of his father, and contemplated killing himself and his family before placing blame on the governing pro-[[Quebec sovereignty movement|sovereignty]] [[Parti Québécois]] for his problems (disliking the party's advocation of a "Francophone identity" for Quebec). Lortie planned the killing spree as a means of broadcasting his discontent. ==Events== ===Prior to the shooting=== On May 7, 1984, Lortie left the [[CFS Carp]] military base (originally built as a [[Diefenbunker]] during the Cold War), pretending that he needed time off to arrange a divorce with his wife. Instead, he rented a car, drove to [[Quebec City]] and took a guided tour of the [[Parliament Building (Quebec)|Parliament Building]]. He then rented a room in a motel for the night. Lortie had previously attempted to secure leave from his base, but was refused. It was during this encounter that Lortie later claimed he saw the face of his father on the face of the officer that denied his request.https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=S_YioojS82I&list=WL&index=1 The next day, May 8, 1984, at 9:30 a.m., Lortie walked into [[CJRP]] radio station in [[Quebec City]], identified himself as "Mr. D", and dropped off a sealed envelope containing an audiotape for one of the station's hosts, [[André Arthur]]. He instructed the radio staff not to open the envelope until 10:30 a.m. but they opened it anyway, discovering that it was a statement of Lortie's plans, in which he declared, "The government now in power is going to be destroyed." However, by the time radio staff contacted police, Lortie's plan had already been put into action. ===The shooting=== At 9:45 a.m., Lortie entered the Parliament Building through a side door located on Grande-Allée. He was dressed in combat fatigues and armed with two [[Sterling submachine gun|C-1 submachine gun]]s, an [[Browning Hi-Power|Inglis pistol]], a duffel bag containing four hundred rounds of [[9mm NATO]] ammunition, as well as a knife strapped to his leg. As he entered the building, he shot and mortally wounded a receptionist, then killed a messenger whom he encountered in a corridor. He then went into a smoking room and shot and wounded a person there before moving to the cafeteria, but finally found his way into the Assembly Chamber, outside of which dozens of armed [[Sûreté du Québec]] (SQ), as well as more than a dozen [[List of special police units#Canada|Groupe d'Intervention]] operatives and [[Service de police de la Ville de Québec|Quebec City Police]] (many carrying [[M1 carbine#Carbine.2C Cal .30.2C M2|M2 carbines]]), helicopters, and snipers were taking position.https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Klm5YwCwK60 Based on later testimony, it is clear that he intended to assassinate Premier [[René Lévesque]] and other members of the governing Parti Québécois. His plan was to enter the Assembly Chamber during the parliamentary committee meeting, which was starting at 10:00 that morning. However, instead of using a watch, Lortie timed his attack by listening to [[CJRP]] and waited for the station's host, André Arthur, to end his segment. Fortunately, on that day, Arthur ended his broadcast 20 minutes early, leading Lortie to enter the building and make his way to the Assembly Chamber while it was mostly empty. Lortie opened fire on the government employees still inside the Assembly Chamber, killing two and wounding 11 others. No politicians were killed or wounded. ===Lortie's surrender=== The National Assembly's [[Sergeant-at-Arms]], [[René Jalbert]], was informed that there was a man in military uniform with a gun in the Assembly Chamber. Upon stepping out of the elevator, Lortie asked him why he came, and fired his [[Sterling submachine gun|C-1 Submachine gun]] inches from his face. Jalbert proceeded to inform him that he too had been a soldier with the [[Van Doos]] (slang for the [[Royal 22nd Regiment]]), and that if Lortie would allow it, he would show him his discharge card. Lortie agreed, after which Jalbert persuaded him to show his own identification. After this exchange, Jalbert persuaded Lortie to come into his office to discuss the matter, and release the other civilians in the Assembly Chamber. Jalbert talked to Lortie for more than four hours, ultimately promising him that he would be able to surrender to military police (since he was unwilling to surrender to civilian police). At 2:15 PM, Lortie surrendered to officers of the SQ, Quebec City Police, and the National Assembly security.http://www.revparl.ca/english/issue.asp?art=603¶m=110 For his heroic actions, which likely prevented further death, the Canadian government awarded Jalbert the [[Cross of Valour (Canada)|Cross of Valour]] several months later, in the same National Assembly chamber that Lortie had burst into. ===Victims=== The following were killed in the shooting: * Georges Boyer * Camille Lepage (not to be confused with the late [[French people|French]] photojournalist [[Camille Lepage]], who was also the victim of an apparent murder) * Roger Lefrançois ==Aftermath== One of the contributing factors to the shooting was, allegedly, the easy access that Lortie had to both weapons and ammunition. Unlike other non-combat Canadian Forces Bases, CFS Carp, the base at which he was stationed, apparently did not have an [[Armory (military)#Operational subdivision|armory]], or even ammunition lockers. According to psychiatrist [[Pierre Mailloux]], who was assigned to the case, Lortie suffered from [[paranoid schizophrenia]] and had organized his crime during a psychotic episode, believing that he was acting on instructions given to him from God. Nevertheless, in 1985, Lortie was convicted of first-degree murder, but a new trial was ordered when the [[Quebec Court of Appeal]] determined the trial judge had made errors while instructing jurors about how they should weigh testimony from psychiatrists heard in the case. Lortie pleaded guilty to reduced charges of second-degree murder in 1987.{{cite web |url=http://www.canada.com/montrealgazette/news/story.html?id=885c67db-68e2-4a59-bccc-26cba6d512b6&k=95107 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2016-01-16 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160116024014/http://www.canada.com/montrealgazette/news/story.html?id=885c67db-68e2-4a59-bccc-26cba6d512b6&k=95107 |archivedate=2016-01-16 |df= }} In 1995, Lortie was released on day parole to a [[halfway house]] in [[Hull, Quebec]], after being released from a minimum security correctional facility north of [[Montreal]] where he had been undergoing psychiatric treatment, classes to deal with aggression, and serving a life sentence with no eligibility for parole for 10 years. According to officials from the [[Parole Board of Canada]], Lortie no longer posed a threat to society, and "patched his life together despite being responsible for one of the most notorious events in Quebec history".{{Citation needed|date=November 2016}} Under the release terms, Lortie was required to spend every night at the halfway house between 11:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. He was also required to let parole board supervisors know where he was at all times, and was restricted to a 40 kilometer (24.8 mile) radius from the house. The relatives of some of Lortie's victims believed he was not punished severely enough, with some believing he should have been [[executed]], a punishment that could not and cannot be applied as Canada abolished its death penalty in 1976.http://www.thecanadianencyclopedia.ca/en/article/lortie-released/ Granted full parole in July 1996 (the same year Jalbert died of cancer), he has since kept a low profile.{{citation needed|date=December 2016}} He is last known to have worked at a [[dépanneur]] in the [[Hull—Aylmer]] district of Quebec,http://coolopolis.blogspot.com/2012/09/dark-moments-for-politics-in-kweeb.html and is now married, with a steady job and a house, and has reportedly been forthcoming with "the people who monitor his case". ==See also== * [[Michael Zehaf-Bibeau]], a 2014 shooter who attacked the Canadian Parliament Buildings Centre Block * [[Paul Joseph Chartier]], who attempted to bomb the Canadian Parliament Building in Ottawa in 1966 * [[List of rampage killers (Americas)]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://archives.cbc.ca/on_this_day/05/08/ CBC Archives] *[http://lesoleil.cyberpresse.ca/journal/2004/05/01/zoom/01135_itineraire_d_un_tueur.php French article in the newspaper Le Soleil describing the events] * [http://www.radio-canada.ca/nouvelles/Index/nouvelles/200405/08/007-Lortie-Assemblee-20-ans.shtml French article describing the event on its 20th anniversary in 2004] * {{BLP sources|date=August 2016}} {{Infobox scientist | name = Edward Belbruno | image = Edward Belbruno explains orbits to NYSkies at YMCA W14 St jeh.jpg | image_size = | alt = | caption = Belbruno lecturing to an astronomy club | birth_date = August 2, 1951 (age 65) | birth_place = [[Heidelberg, Germany]] | residence = | citizenship = | nationality = | fields = Celestial mechanics | workplaces = [[Jet Propulsion Laboratory]], 1985 - 1990 | alma_mater = [[New York University]] | thesis_title = | thesis_url = | thesis_year = | doctoral_advisor = | academic_advisors = | doctoral_students = | notable_students = | known_for = | author_abbrev_bot = | author_abbrev_zoo = | influences = | influenced = | awards = | signature = <!--(filename only)--> | signature_alt = | website = {{URL|www.edbelbruno.com}} | footnotes = | spouse = | children = }} '''Edward Belbruno''' (born August 2, 1951 in [[Heidelberg, Germany]]) is an artist, mathematician and scientist whose interests are in [[celestial mechanics]], dynamical systems, dynamical astronomy, and aerospace engineering. His artistic media is paintings. Belbruno received his associate degree from [[Mitchell College]], his Bachelor of Science degree in mathematics from [[New York University]] and his PhD in mathematics from New York University’s [[Courant Institute]] in 1981, where his mentor was mathematician [[Jürgen Moser]]. He was employed by the [[Jet Propulsion Laboratory]] from 1985 to 1990 as an orbital analyst on such missions as [[Galileo (spacecraft)|Galileo]], [[Magellan (spacecraft)|Magellan]], [[Cassini (spacecraft)|Cassini]], [[Ulysses (spacecraft)|Ulysses]], [[Mars Observer]], and others. His artwork in the NASA collection, Charles Betlach II collection, and exhibited in Paris, Rome, Los Angeles, Washington DC, New York City, Minneapolis, Shanghai, WeiHai, and Princeton.
During that time, he laid the foundations for the first systematic application of [[chaos theory]] to space flight originally called [[Interplanetary travel#Fuzzy orbits|fuzzy boundary theory]], which allows for the construction of very low energy paths for spacecraft.
In 1990 Belbruno applied his ideas for [[low energy transfer]] orbits to the Japanese lunar probe [[Hiten]], which had been designed only for lunar swing-by and had suffered a failure of the Hagoromo lunar orbiter. The main Hiten probe lacked the fuel to enter lunar orbit using a conventional [[Hohmann transfer orbit|Hohmann transfer trajectory]], but Belbruno was able to devise a ballistic capture trajectory that would put it in lunar orbit using only a negligible amount of fuel. The probe entered lunar orbit in 1991, the first time that Belbruno's ideas had been put to the test.
Belbruno had first proposed using a low-energy transfer orbit for a JPL probe in 1988. However, he faced a great deal of skepticism, and found himself in conflict with engineers. He had also expected to make no progress on ''Hiten'', but the Japanese proved receptive to his ideas and called ballistic capture an "amazing result." He left JPL in fall of 1990 and took a position at [[Pomona College]].<ref name="belbruno_fly">Belbruno, Edward. ''Fly me to the moon: an insider's guide to the new science of space travel''. Princeton University Press, 2007.</ref>
Belbruno is president and founder of the company Innovative Orbital Design, Inc., based in [[Princeton, New Jersey]] and holds patents on routes in space. He consulted on the rescue of the [[PAS-22|Asiasat-3]] communications satellite for Hughes, although a different trajectory was ultimately used for the rescue.
Belbruno's books include ''Fly Me to the Moon'' and ''Capture Dynamics and Chaotic Motions in Celestial Mechanics''. He is a consultant with the [[National Aeronautics and Space Administration]], and has made appearances on NBC's [[Today (NBC program)|''Today Show'']] and NPR's 360. He was invited by TedX to give a talk on his art, math and science.

'''George Gifford''' (c.1548–1620) was a Puritan preacher at [[Maldon, Essex|Maldon]], [[Essex]].
==Life==
Gifford was born in [[Dry Drayton]], near [[Cambridge]] and attended [[Christ's College, Cambridge]], graduating BA in 1570 and MA in 1573.<ref>{{acad|id=GFRT569G|name=Giffard, George}}</ref> He afterwards lived at Maldon, but was discharged from the priesthood for refusing to subscribe to Archbishop Whitgift's articles of conformity. He was later reinstated as a lecturer at Maldon, serving there as a lecturer until his death in 1600.
It is possible that in 1586 he attended the deathbed of Sir Philip Sidney in the Low Countries, where Gifford was serving as chaplain to the Earl of Essex's troops. Gifford may well have penned ''The Manner of Sir Philip Sidney's Death''.
==Works==
Gifford wrote some twenty-two published works. These include a translation of [[William Fulke]]'s ''Praelections vpon the sacred and holy Reuelation of S. Iohn'' (1573; STC:11443); ''A briefe discourse of certaine points of the religion which is among the common sort of Christians, which may bee termed the countrie diunitie'' (1581; STC:11845), which was his most popular work; ''A dialogue betweene a Papist and a Protestant'' (1582; STC:11849); and two works on witchcraft, ''A discourse of the subtill practises of deuilles by witches and sorcerers'' (1587; STC:11852) and ''A Dialogue Concerning Witches and Witchcrafts'' (1593; STC:11850). It is the last work for which he is best known.
Gifford was a moderate in the [[witchcraft]] debate, although he still believed in the existence of witches, and that they should be severely punished. His main concern in the ''Dialogue'' was to ensure more care was taken in witchcraft prosecutions, and to attempt to restrain the persecuting fervour with which witches were sought out and indicted.

S., ''George Gifford and the Reformation of the Common Sort – Puritan Priorities in Elizabethan Religious Life'' (Truman State University Press, 2004) * A modern spelling reprint of the ''Dialogue'' is available from Puckrel Publishing.

revision.comment: Robot - Speedily moving category Greek people of the Greco-Turkish War (1919–22) to [[:Category:Greek people of the Greco-Turkish War (1919–1922)]] per [[WP:CFDS|CFDS]].
revision.text:
{{hatnote|Not to be confused with [[George Prokopiou]], the Greek ship owner.}} [[File:George-Prokopiou-the-Painter-01-egypt-1907-high.jpg|thumb|200px|Georgios Prokopiou (1907; possibly a wedding picture)]] '''Georgios Prokopiou''' (Greek: Γεώργιος Προκοπίου; 1876, in [[İzmir|Smyrna]] – 20 December 1940, near [[Tepelenë]]) was a Greek [[war artist]], photographer and [[documentary film]] maker. He also served as [[court painter]] to Emperor [[Menelik II]] and was a recipient of the Greek Military Cross.[http://www.aspromavro.net/alx/articles1/afieromata/229-prokopiou-giorgos.html Brief biography] @ Aspromavro. == Biography == At the age of fifteen he was working as an [[icon]] painter and attracted the attention of Hortense Wood, an English artist who was living near Smyrna. She gave him drawing lessons and presented his work to [[Nikiforos Lytras]], who recommended Prokopiou to the [[Athens School of Fine Arts]]. He enrolled there in 1895, studying with Lytras and [[Georgios Roilos]]. In 1901, after completing his studies, he returned to Smyrna and held his first exhibition. Two years later, he travelled to Alexandria and Cairo, where he painted portraits of notable figures in the Greek communities there, including [[Pavlos Melas]], who introduced him to the head of Ethiopia's diplomatic mission.[http://www.tovima.gr/culture/article/?aid=373525 Biographical notes] @ To Vima. [[File:Prokopiou-Studio.JPG|thumb|left|275px|Prokopiou in his studio (late 1920s)]] This resulted in an invitation to visit [[Addis Ababa]] to do a portrait of Emperor Menelik. He went there by caravan from [[Djibouti (city)|Djibouti]], accompanied by his brother Socrates, who would later write a book about the trip. After competing with several other painters, he was chosen to become the Court Painter in 1905. In addition to painting the [[Solomonic Dynasty|Royal Family]], he portrayed several ambassadors as well as landscapes and village scenes. Lavish with honors, the Emperor awarded him the [[Order of Solomon]], the [[Order of the Star of Ethiopia]] and other lesser-known medals. In 1907, he returned to Athens to marry, travelled extensively, and settled in Smyrna in 1913. The beginning of [[World War I]] found Smyrna blockaded by the [[Allies of World War I|Allies]]. Soon after, the [[Ottomans]] began persecuting Christians. This included setting up "labor battalions" which were soon revealed as actually being death battalions. Most of the Greek population, including Prokopiou and his family, went into hiding. Somehow, he found work as an art teacher for the daughter of an Ottoman official, which afforded him protection. It was at this time that he created his first war art; depictions of the [[Naval operations in the Dardanelles Campaign|campaign in the Dardanelles]]. ===Greco-Turkish and Greco-Italian Wars=== [[File:PROKOPIOU-EPITESI.jpg|thumb|200px|Greek attack on the Albanian front (1940)]] After the war, Smyrna came under [[Occupation of Smyrna|Greek control]]. The following year, General [[Leonidas Paraskevopoulos]] commissioned him to produce paintings, photographs and films of the Greek campaigns against the Turks during the [[Greco-Turkish War (1919–22)|Greco-Turkish War]].[http://istoria.gr/aug02/3.htm Brief Biography] @ Istoria. Although they admired his courage, a few commanders complained that his activities interfered with military operations. After the [[Liberation of İzmir|Turkish recapture of Smyrna]], he returned home to be with his family and remained to take photographs of the [[Great Fire of Smyrna|Great Fire]]. When the chaos had subsided, he was arrested and sentenced to death by a Turkish tribunal. Luckily, the prison commandant allowed him to say goodbye to his family. With the assistance of his neighbors and the French Consul, he and his family were able to escape aboard a French ship that took them to [[Piraeus]]. In 1925, he settled in Athens. He continued to paint military scenes from memory until 1928, after which he produced a variety of nudes, scenes of ruins and portraits, including one of [[Haile Selassie]], who visited his studio shortly before becoming Emperor. In 1940, the [[Greco-Italian War]] began when Greece refused to capitulate to the [[Axis Powers]]. Although Prokopiou was sixty-four years old and ill with [[bronchitis]], he went to the War Ministry, begging to be sent to the front. Finally, he wrote to Prime Minister [[Ioannis Metaxas|Metaxas]], saying that he was ashamed to stay at home when his two sons were out fighting for Greece. Metaxas agreed to his request, and Prokopiou left for Albania to join the Greek counter-offensive. He met up with his son, Angelos, sketching and taking photographs almost immediately. One night, several weeks later, when the temperature fell below zero, he died of heart failure. He was given the posthumous rank of Colonel, brought back to Athens, and buried with full military honors. ==Selected paintings== File:PROKOPIOU-NERO-10.jpg|Soldier Drinking File:PROKOPIOU-ANAPAYSI.jpg|Resting from Battle File:To the Last Man Prokopiou.jpg|To the Last Man File:PROKOPIOU-TAITOY.jpg|Ethiopian Empress
[[Taytu Betul]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{commons category|Georgios Prokopiou}} *[http://www.pemptousia.gr/2011/10/%CE%B3%CE%B9%CF%8E%CF%81%CE%B3%CE%BF%CF%82-%CF%80%CF%81%CE%BF%CE%BA%CE%BF%CF%80%CE%AF%CE%BF%CF%85-%CE%BF-%CF%80%CE%BF%CE%BB%CE%B5%CE%BC%CE%B9%CE%BA%CF%8C%CF%82-%CE%B6%CF%89%CE%B3%CF%81%CE%AC%CF%86/ An appreciation of Prokopiou as a war artist] @ Pemptousia. Contains the text of his letter to Metaxas. {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Prokopiou, Georgios}} [[Category:1876 births]] [[Category:1940 deaths]] [[Category:Greek painters]] [[Category:War artists]] [[Category:People from Izmir]] [[Category:Smyrniote Greeks]] [[Category:Greeks of the Ottoman Empire]] [[Category:Portrait painters]] [[Category:Greek people of the Greco-Turkish War (1919–1922)]] [[Category:Greek photographers]] [[Category:Greek people of World War II]] [[Category:Court painters]] [[Category:Recipients of the Order of the Star of Ethiopia]]

{{DISPLAYTITLE:Kevin (''Sin City'')}} {{Cleanup|date=November 2011}} {{Infobox character | color = black | color text = white | name = Kevin | series = [[Sin City]] | image = Kevin in Sin City 2005.jpg | caption = Kevin in the [[Sin City (film)|2005 adaptation of Sin City]] | first = ''[[List of Sin City yarns#The Hard Goodbye|The Hard Goodbye]]'' | last = | creator = [[Frank Miller (comics)|Frank Miller]] | portrayer = [[Elijah Wood]] | gender = Male | lbl1 = | data1 = [[Dark Horse Comics]] | fullname = | lbl21 = Affiliation(s) | data21 = [[Dwight McCarthy]]
[[Nancy Callahan]]
[[List of characters from Sin City#Female protagonists|Goldie and Wendy]] }} '''Kevin''' is a fictional character in [[Frank Miller (comics)|Frank Miller]]'s [[graphic novel]] series ''[[Sin City (comics)|Sin City]]'', featured prominently in ''[[The Hard Goodbye]]''. He is a [[muteness|mute]], [[cannibalism|cannibalistic]] [[serial killer]] who preys on the titular city's prostitutes, [[The Girls of Old Town]]. He is protected by the powerful Cardinal Patrick Henry Roark, who also acts as his accomplice. Kevin lives at the [[Roark family]] farm, and uses the basement as an execution chamber for his victims; after he kills and eats them, he stuffs and mounts their heads on the walls like hunting trophies. While he appears harmless and unassuming, Kevin is a fierce, inhumanly fast fighter adept in [[martial arts]]; accordingly, the Roark family uses him as an [[assassin]] from time to time. He is usually accompanied by his pet wolf, which he feeds whatever parts of his victims he does not eat himself. ==Appearances== ===''The Hard Goodbye''=== ''The Hard Goodbye'' establishes Kevin's back story, as related by Cardinal Roark. He first meets Roark when going to him for [[Confession (religion)|confession]], wracked with guilt over the murders he is committing. Roark eventually comes to believe that Kevin is doing God's work by consuming his victims' souls as well as their bodies, and eventually joins him in cannibalistic rituals. Roark also claims that Kevin is [[selective mutism|mute by choice]], and when he speaks it is with "the voice of an angel". In the main plot, Kevin kills [[Marv (Sin City)|Marv]]'s one true love, Goldie, at Cardinal Roark's behest when she learns the truth about their murder spree; he then frames Marv for the crime. Marv swears revenge, and cuts a bloody swath through the city's underworld until he learns the identity of the killer he seeks. He then follows Kevin to the Farm, where Kevin surprises him and knocks him unconscious. He also kidnaps and imprisons Marv's parole officer, Lucille, and forces her to watch while he eats her hand. Marv eventually escapes, however, and confronts Kevin again. This time, Marv overpowers him and subjects him to brutal, systematic torture, eventually sawing his limbs off and feeding him to his pet wolf. Much to Marv's frustration, Kevin does not make a sound the entire time, and dies with a blissful smile on his face. ===''That Yellow Bastard''=== Kevin makes a cameo appearance in ''[[That Yellow Bastard]]'', set a few years before ''The Hard Goodbye''. He appears at the Farm, sitting in a rocking chair and reading the [[Bible]] while Roark Junior tortures [[Nancy Callahan]]. ==In other media== Kevin is portrayed by [[Elijah Wood]] in [[Robert Rodriguez]]'s [[Sin city (film)|2005 film adaptation of ''Sin City'']].{{cite web|url=http://www.totalfilm.com/features/30-craziest-movie-casting-moments|title=30 Craziest Movie Casting Moments | TotalFilm.com|publisher=totalfilm.com|accessdate=2014-08-26}}{{cite web|url=http://www.reelz.com/movie-news/4382/elijah-wood-discusses-sin-city-9-and-the-hobbit/ |title=REELZ: Movie News |publisher=reelz.com |accessdate=2014-08-26 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140819083614/http://www.reelz.com/movie-news/4382/elijah-wood-discusses-sin-city-9-and-the-hobbit/ |archivedate=2014-08-19 |df= }} ==Character notes== Frank Miller has stated in the ''Sin City: Recut and Extended'' DVD commentary that Kevin and another supporting character, [[Miho (Sin City)|Miho]], are the supernatural beings in Sin City. Miller characterizes them as "[[demon]]s"; Miho is a good "demon" and Kevin is an evil one. ==Reception== In 2011, [[UGO Networks]] ranked Kevin together with Miho as #1 in their list "Quiet as the Grave: The Silent Killers of Film and TV".{{cite web|last1=Fitzpatrick|first1=Kevin|title=Quiet as the Grave: The Silent Killers of Film and TV|url=http://www.ugo.com/tv/silent-killers-miho-kevin|website=Ugo.com|accessdate=4 July 2017|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140529210346/http://www.ugo.com/tv/silent-killers-miho-kevin|archivedate=May 29, 2014|date=January 31, 2011}} ==References== {{Reflist}} {{SinCity}} [[Category:Sin City characters]] [[Category:Fictional serial killers]] [[Category:Fictional cannibals]] [[Category:Comic martial artists]] [[Category:Comics characters introduced in 1991]] [[Category:Crime film characters]] [[Category:Fictional demons and devils]] [[Category:Characters created by Frank Miller]] [[Category:Fictional assassins]] [[Category:Psychopathy in fiction]] [[Category:Fictional torturers]]

'''Leonard A. Jason''' is a professor of psychology at [[DePaul University]] in [[Chicago]], [[Illinois]], where he also directs the Center for Community Research.<ref>https://csh.depaul.edu/faculty-staff/faculty-a-z/Pages/psychology/leonard-jason.aspx</ref><ref name="Home Page"/> His chief professional interests include the study of [[chronic fatigue syndrome]] (CFS), myalgic encephalomyelitis (ME), violence prevention, [[smoking cessation]], and [[Oxford House]] recovery homes for substance abuse.<ref name="Home Page">{{cite web |title=Leonard A. Jason's Home Page |publisher=DePaul University |url=http://condor.depaul.edu/~ljason/ |accessdate = 12 January 2009}}</ref> Jason's interest in chronic fatigue syndrome began when he was diagnosed with the condition in 1990 after having [[mononucleosis]].<ref name=timesinterview>{{cite news |first=David |last=Tuller |title=Times Essentials: Expert Q&A—Learning Firsthand about Chronic Fatigue Syndrome |url=https://www.nytimes.com/ref/health/healthguide/esn-chronicfatigue-expert.html |publisher=The New York Times |date=May 30, 2008 |accessdate=2 September 2009}}</ref>
==Early life and education== Leonard A. Jason is the son of [[Jay Jason]], a well known comedian who entertained in the [[Catskills Mountains]]. Jason received a B.A. in psychology from [[Brandeis University]] in [[Waltham, Massachusetts]] in 1971 and a Ph.D. in psychology from the [[University of Rochester]] in [[Rochester, New York]] in 1975.
==Career== Jason is a former president of the Division of Community Psychology of the [[American Psychological Association]] (APA) and a past editor of ''The Community Psychologist''.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.scra27.org/files/7914/1791/3565/TCP_192_Spring_1986.pdf|title=The Community Psychologist (1986) |accessdate=11 November 2016}}</ref> Jason has edited or written 28 books, and he has published over 800 articles and 100 book chapters on CFS, ME, recovery homes, the prevention of alcohol, tobacco, and other drug abuse, media interventions and program evaluation. He has served on 92 Thesis Committees (of which he chaired 64), and 102 Dissertation Committees (of which he chaired 52). He has served on the editorial boards of ten psychological journals. Jason has served on review committees of the National Institutes of Health, and he has received over $36,000,000 in federal research grants.<ref name="Home Page"/> He was also a board member and vice-president for a scientific professional organization called the International Association of CFS/ME.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://iacfsme.org/Home.aspx|periodical=IACFS/ME Newsletter|title=IACFS/ME|accessdate=25 November 2016}}</ref>
He was a member the Chronic Fatigue Syndrome Advisory Committee.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.hhs.gov/ash/advisory-committees/cfsac/index.html# |title=Chronic Fatigue Syndrome Advisory Committee|accessdate=25 November 2016}}</ref> In 1999, Jason published an epidemiological study of chronic fatigue syndrome among United States adults.<ref name="PMID_10527290">{{cite journal |author = Jason, LA|title=A community-based study of chronic fatigue syndrome |journal=Arch Intern Med |volume=159 |issue=18 |pages=2129–37 |year=1999 |url=http://archinte.ama-assn.org/cgi/content/full/159/18/2129 |pmid= 10527290 |accessdate=12 January 2009 |doi = 10.1001/archinte.159.18.2129|display-authors=etal}}</ref> Jason helped organize two major American Psychological Association sponsored conferences on research methods for community psychology <ref>Tolan, P., Keys, C., Chertok, F., & Jason, L. (Eds.). (1990). [http://psycnet.apa.org/psycinfo/1990-98742-000 Researching community psychology: Issues of theories and methods.Washington, DC: American Psychological Association]</ref><ref>Jason, L.A., Keys, C.B., Suarez-Balcazar, Y., Taylor, R.R., Davis, M., Durlak, J., Isenberg, D. (Eds.) (2004). [http://www.apa.org/pubs/books/4318003.aspx Participatory community research: Theories and methods in action.Washington, DC: American Psychological Association]</ref> and co-edited a book on this topic.<ref>Jason, L.A., & Glenwick, D.S. (Eds.) (2012). [http://www.apa.org/pubs/books/4316136.aspx Methodological Approaches to Community-Based Research. Washington, DC: American Psychological Association].</ref>
Jason has served on the editorial boards of journals including: * ''Journal of Community Psychology'', 1983–1986, 2007–present.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www3.interscience.wiley.com/journal/32213/home/EditorialBoard.html |title=Journal of Community Psychology |work=Journals |publisher=Wiley InterScience |accessdate=2 September 2009}}</ref> * ''Prevention in Human Services'', 1986–1995; renamed Journal of ''Prevention and Intervention in the Community'', 1996–present.<ref>{{cite book |url=http://www.haworthpressinc.com/store/product.asp?sku=J005|title=Journal of Prevention and Intervention in the Community |accessdate=12 January 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080512060151/http://www.haworthpressinc.com/store/product.asp?sku=J005 |archivedate=12 May 2008}}</ref> * ''Journal of Health Psychology'', 2008–present.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://hpq.sagepub.com/|title=Journal of Health Psychology|website=hpq.sagepub.com|access-date=2016-09-08}}</ref> * ''Fatigue: Biomedicine, Health & Behavior,'' 2013–present''.''<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.tandfonline.com/toc/rftg20/current|title=Fatigue: Biomedicine, Health & Behavior: Vol 4, No 3|website=www.tandfonline.com|access-date=2016-09-08}}</ref> * ''The Journal of Primary Prevention'', 1983–2007. Appointed Associate Editor, 1986–2007.<ref name="Home Page" /> * ''Special Services in the Schools''; renamed ''Journal of Applied School Psychology'' 1984–2008.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.tandfonline.com/toc/wapp20/24/2?nav=tocList |title=Journal of Applied School Psychology |accessdate=12 January 2009}}</ref> * ''American Journal of Community Psychology'', 1978–1991. Appointed Associate Editor, 1983–1987.<ref>[https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/journal/15732770 American Journal of Community Psychology]</ref> * ''Professional Psychology,'' 1978–1991.<ref>[http://www.apa.org/pubs/journals/pro/ Professional Psychology]</ref> * ''Behaviorists for Social Action,'' 1983–1990.<ref>[http://journals.uic.edu/ojs/index.php/bsi/pages/view/predj Behaviorists for Social Action]</ref> * ''Journal of Applied Behavior Analysis,'' 1986–1991.<ref>[https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/journal/19383703 Journal of Applied Behavior Analysis]</ref>
==Honors and awards== In 1991, Jason was provided the Ethnic Minority Mentorship Award from the Society for Community Research and Action.<ref>[http://www.scra27.org/members1/member-awards/scra-awards/ethnic-and-minority-mentoring-award/ Ethnic and Minority Mentoring Award]</ref> He received in 1997 the Distinguished Contributions to Theory and Research Award from the Society for Community Research and Action.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.scra27.org/members1/member-awards/scra-awards/theory-and-research-award/|title=Award for Distinguished Contributions to Theory and Research in Community Psychology |publisher=Society for Community Research and Action |accessdate=25 November 2016}}</ref> He was presented the 1997 CFIDS Support Network ACTION Champion Award by the [[Chronic Fatigue Immune Dysfunction Syndrome Association of America]]. He was presented in 1998 with DePaul University's Cortelyou–Lowery Award for Excellence.<ref>[http://wdat.is.depaul.edu/newsroom/year_2000/594.html DePaul University News Archives (1997-2014).]</ref> He received the Dutch ME Foundation International ME Award in 2003.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.prohealth.com/library/showarticle.cfm?libid=9810 |title=Award |publisher=ProHealth |accessdate=25 November 2016}}</ref> In 2007, he received the Special Contribution to Public Policy Award from the Society for Community Research and Action.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.scra27.org/members1/member-awards/scra-awards/policy-award/ |title=Award for Special Contributions to Public Policy |publisher=Society for Community Research and Action |accessdate=25 November 2016}}</ref> He was awarded the 2011 Perpich Award by the International Association for Chronic Fatigue Syndrome/Myalgic Encephalomyelitis (IACFS/ME) for distinguished community service.<ref>http://iacfsme.org/Organization/Former-IACFS-ME-Awardees.aspx</ref> Also in 2011, he was presented with the Tom Fellows Award by the Oxford House Organization for 20 years of research documenting the process of long term recovery from addiction.<ref>[http://www.oxfordhouse.org/userfiles/file/doc/ar2011.pdf Oxford House, Inc. Annual Report Fiscal Year 2011]</ref> In 2013, Jason was presented with the DePaul University’s College of Science and Health’s Excellence in Research Award.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://csh.depaul.edu/research/faculty-research/Pages/excellence-in-research-award.aspx|title=Excellence in Research Award {{!}} Faculty Research {{!}} Research {{!}} College of Science and Health {{!}} DePaul University|website=csh.depaul.edu|access-date=2016-09-07}}</ref> In 2015, he was presented the [[American Psychological Association]]’s award for [[APA Award for Distinguished Professional Contributions to Applied Research|Distinguished Professional Contributions to Applied Research]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://psycnet.apa.org/index.cfm?fa=buy.optionToBuy&id=2015-53340-028|title=PsycNET—Option to Buy|website=psycnet.apa.org|access-date=2016-09-07}}</ref>
